title: The Ones Who Walk Away From Omelas

title: The Ones Who Walk Away From Omelas

title: The Ones Who Walk Away From Omelas

title: The Ones Who Walk Away From Omelas

title: The Ones Who Walk Away From Omelas

title: The Ones Who Walk Away From Omelas

text:
Sultanas Dream

One evening I was lounging in an easy chair in my bedroom and thinking lazily of
the condition of Indian womanhood. I am not sure whether I dozed off or not. But,
as far as I remember, I was wide awake. I saw the moonlit sky sparkling with
thousands of diamond-like stars, very distinctly.
All on a sudden a lady stood before me; how she came in, I do not know. I took
her for my friend, Sister Sara.
Good morning, said Sister Sara. I smiled inwardly as I knew it was not morning,
but starry night. However, I replied to her, saying, How do you do?
I am all right, thank you. Will you please come out and have a look at our
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
garden?
I looked again at the moon through the open window, and thought there was no
harm in going out at that time. The men-servants outside were fast asleep just then,
and I could have a pleasant walk with Sister Sara.
I used to have my walks with Sister Sara, when we were at Darjeeling. Many a
time did we walk hand in hand and talk light-heartedly in the botanical gardens
there. I fancied, Sister Sara had probably come to take me to some such garden
and I readily accepted her offer and went out with her.
When walking I found to my surprise that it was a fine morning. The town was
fully awake and the streets alive with bustling crowds. I was feeling very shy,
thinking I was walking in the street in broad daylight, but there was not a single
man visible.
Some of the passers-by made jokes at me. Though I could not understand their
language, yet I felt sure they were joking. I asked my friend, What do they say?
The women say that you look very mannish.
Mannish? said I, What do they mean by that?
They mean that you are shy and timid like men.



Sultanas Dream

Page No - 4

Shy and timid like men? It was really a joke. I became very nervous, when I
found that my companion was not Sister Sara, but a stranger. Oh, what a fool had I
been to mistake this lady for my dear old friend, Sister Sara.
She felt my fingers tremble in her hand, as we were walking hand in hand.
What is the matter, dear? she said affectionately. I feel somewhat awkward, I
said in a rather apologizing tone, as being a purdahnishin woman I am not
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
accustomed to walking about unveiled.
You need not be afraid of coming across a man here. This is Ladyland, free from
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
sin and harm. Virtue herself reigns here.
By and by I was enjoying the scenery. Really it was very grand. I mistook a patch
of green grass for a velvet cushion. Feeling as if I were walking on a soft carpet, I
looked down and found the path covered with moss and flowers.
How nice it is, said I.
Do you like it? asked Sister Sara. (I continued calling her Sister Sara, and she
kept calling me by my name).
Yes, very much; but I do not like to tread on the tender and sweet flowers.
Never mind, dear Sultana; your treading will not harm them; they are street
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
flowers.
The whole place looks like a garden, said I admiringly. You have arranged every
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
plant so skillfully.
Your Calcutta could become a nicer garden than this if only your countrymen
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
wanted to make it so.
They would think it useless to give so much attention to horticulture, while they
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
have so many other things to do.
They could not find a better excuse, said she with smile.
I became very curious to know where the men were. I met more than a hundred
women while walking there, but not a single man.
Where are the men? I asked her.
In their proper places, where they ought to be.

Sultanas Dream

Page No - 5

Pray let me know what you mean by their proper places.
O, I see my mistake, you cannot know our customs, as you were never here
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
before. We shut our men indoors.
Just as we are kept in the zenana?
Exactly so.
How funny, I burst into a laugh. Sister Sara laughed too.
But dear Sultana, how unfair it is to shut in the harmless women and let loose the
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
men.
Why? It is not safe for us to come out of the zenana, as we are naturally weak.
Yes, it is not safe so long as there are men about the streets, nor is it so when a
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
wild animal enters a marketplace.
Of course not.
Suppose, some lunatics escape from the asylum and begin to do all sorts of
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: mischief to men, horses and other creatures; in that case what will your
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
countrymen do?
They will try to capture them and put them back into their asylum.
Thank you! And you do not think it wise to keep sane people inside an asylum
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
and let loose the insane?
Of course not! said I laughing lightly.
As a matter of fact, in your country this very thing is done! Men, who do or at
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: least are capable of doing no end of mischief, are let loose and the innocent
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: women, shut up in the zenana! How can you trust those untrained men out of
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
doors?
We have no hand or voice in the management of our social affairs. In India man is
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: lord and master, he has taken to himself all powers and privileges and shut up the
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
women in the zenana.
Why do you allow yourselves to be shut up?
Because it cannot be helped as they are stronger than women.



Sultanas Dream

Page No - 6

A lion is stronger than a man, but it does not enable him to dominate the human
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: race. You have neglected the duty you owe to yourselves and you have lost your
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
natural rights by shutting your eyes to your own interests.
But my dear Sister Sara, if we do everything by ourselves, what will the men do
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
then?
They should not do anything, excuse me; they are fit for nothing. Only catch them
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
and put them into the zenana.
But would it be very easy to catch and put them inside the four walls? said I. And
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: even if this were done, would all their business ì political and commercial ì also
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
go with them into the zenana?
Sister Sara made no reply. She only smiled sweetly. Perhaps she thought it useless
to argue with one who was no better than a frog in a well.
By this time we reached Sister Saras house. It was situated in a beautiful heartshaped garden. It was a bungalow with a corrugated iron roof. It was cooler and
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: nicer than any of our rich buildings. I cannot describe how neat and how nicely
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: furnished and how tastefully decorated it was.
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: We sat side by side. She brought out of the parlour a piece of embroidery work
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: and began putting on a fresh design.
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: Do you know knitting and needle work?
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: Yes; we have nothing else to do in our zenana.
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
But we do not trust our zenana members with embroidery! she said laughing, as a
man has not patience enough to pass thread through a needlehole even!
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: Have you done all this work yourself? I asked her pointing to the various pieces
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: of embroidered teapoy cloths.
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: Yes.
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
How can you find time to do all these? You have to do the office work as well?
Have you not?
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: Yes. I do not stick to the laboratory all day long. I finish my work in two hours.
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
In two hours! How do you manage? In our land the officers, ì magistrates, for
instance ì work seven hours daily.
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: Sultanas Dream
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: Page No - 7
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
I have seen some of them doing their work. Do you think they work all the seven
hours?
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: Certainly they do!
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
No, dear Sultana, they do not. They dawdle away their time in smoking. Some
smoke two or three choroots during the office time. They talk much about their
work, but do little. Suppose one choroot takes half an hour to burn off, and a man
smokes twelve choroots daily; then you see, he wastes six hours every day in sheer
smoking.
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: We talked on various subjects, and I learned that they were not subject to any kind
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: of epidemic disease, nor did they suffer from mosquito bites as we do. I was very
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: much astonished to hear that in Ladyland no one died in youth except by rare
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: accident.
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: Will you care to see our kitchen? she asked me.
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: With pleasure, said I, and we went to see it. Of course the men had been asked to
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: clear off when I was going there. The kitchen was situated in a beautiful vegetable
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: garden. Every creeper, every tomato plant was itself an ornament. I found no
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: smoke, nor any chimney either in the kitchen -- it was clean and bright; the
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: windows were decorated with flower gardens. There was no sign of coal or fire.
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: How do you cook? I asked.
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: With solar heat, she said, at the same time showing me the pipe, through which
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: passed the concentrated sunlight and heat. And she cooked something then and
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: there to show me the process.
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: How did you manage to gather and store up the sun-heat? I asked her in
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: amazement.
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
Let me tell you a little of our past history then. Thirty years ago, when our present
Queen was thirteen years old, she inherited the throne. She was Queen in name
only, the Prime Minister really ruling the country.
Our good Queen liked science very much. She circulated an order that all the
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
women in her country should be educated. Accordingly a number of girls schools
were founded and supported by the government. Education was spread far and
wide among women. And early marriage also was stopped. No woman was to be
allowed to marry before she was twenty-one. I must tell you that, before this
change we had been kept in strict purdah.
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: Sultanas Dream
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: Page No - 8
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: How the tables are turned, I interposed with a laugh.
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
But the seclusion is the same, she said. In a few years we had separate
universities, where no men were admitted.
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
In the capital, where our Queen lives, there are two universities. One of these
invented a wonderful balloon, to which they attached a number of pipes. By means
of this captive balloon which they managed to keep afloat above the cloud-land,
they could draw as much water from the atmosphere as they pleased. As the water
was incessantly being drawn by the university people no cloud gathered and the
ingenious Lady Principal stopped rain and storms thereby.
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: Really! Now I understand why there is no mud here! said I. But I could not
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: understand how it was possible to accumulate water in the pipes. She explained to
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: me how it was done, but I was unable to understand her, as my scientific
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
knowledge was very limited. However, she went on, When the other university
came to know of this, they became exceedingly jealous and tried to do something
more extraordinary still. They invented an instrument by which they could collect
as much sun-heat as they wanted. And they kept the heat stored up to be
distributed among others as required.
While the women were engaged in scientific research, the men of this country
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: were busy increasing their military power. When they came to know that the
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: female universities were able to draw water from the atmosphere and collect heat
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: from the sun, they only laughed at the members of the universities and called the
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
whole thing a sentimental nightmare!
Your achievements are very wonderful indeed! But tell me, how you managed to
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
put the men of your country into the zenana. Did you entrap them first?
No.
It is not likely that they would surrender their free and open air life of their own
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: accord and confine themselves within the four walls of the zenana! They must
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
have been overpowered.
Yes, they have been!
By whom? By some lady-warriors, I suppose?
No, not by arms.
Yes, it cannot be so. Mens arms are stronger than womens. Then?


Sultanas Dream

Page No - 9

By brain.
Even their brains are bigger and heavier than womens. Are they not?
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
Yes, but what of that? An elephant also has got a bigger and heavier brain than a
man has. Yet man can enchain elephants and employ them, according to their own
wishes.
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: Well said, but tell me please, how it all actually happened. I am dying to know it!
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
Womens brains are somewhat quicker than mens. Ten years ago, when the
military officers called our scientific discoveries "a sentimental nightmare," some
of the young ladies wanted to say something in reply to those remarks. But both
the Lady Principals restrained them and said, they should reply not by word, but
by deed, if ever they got the opportunity. And they had not long to wait for that
opportunity.
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
How marvelous! I heartily clapped my hands. And now the proud gentlemen are
dreaming sentimental dreams themselves.
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
Soon afterwards certain persons came from a neighbouring country and took
shelter in ours. They were in trouble having committed some political offense. The
king who cared more for power than for good government asked our kind-hearted
Queen to hand them over to his officers. She refused, as it was against her
principle to turn out refugees. For this refusal the king declared war against our
country.
Our military officers sprang to their feet at once and marched out to meet the
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: enemy. The enemy however, was too strong for them. Our soldiers fought bravely,
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: no doubt. But in spite of all their bravery the foreign army advanced step by step
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: to invade our country.
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
Nearly all the men had gone out to fight; even a boy of sixteen was not left home.
Most of our warriors were killed, the rest driven back and the enemy came within
twenty-five miles of the capital.
A meeting of a number of wise ladies was held at the Queens palace to advise as
to what should be done to save the land. Some proposed to fight like soldiers;
others objected and said that women were not trained to fight with swords and
guns, nor were they accustomed to fighting with any weapons. A third party
regretfully remarked that they were hopelessly weak of body.


Sultanas Dream

Page No - 10

If you cannot save your country for lack of physical strength, said the Queen,
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: try to do so by brain power.
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
There was a dead silence for a few minutes. Her Royal Highness said again, "I
must commit suicide if the land and my honour are lost."
Then the Lady Principal of the second university (who had collected sun-heat),
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: who had been silently thinking during the consultation, remarked that they were
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: all but lost, and there was little hope left for them. There was, however, one plan
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: which she would like to try, and this would be her first and last efforts; if she
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: failed in this, there would be nothing left but to commit suicide. All present
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: solemnly vowed that they would never allow themselves to be enslaved, no matter
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: what happened.
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
The Queen thanked them heartily, and asked the Lady Principal to try her plan.
The Lady Principal rose again and said, "before we go out the men must enter the
zenanas. I make this prayer for the sake of purdah." "Yes, of course," replied Her
Royal Highness.
On the following day the Queen called upon all men to retire into zenanas for the
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: sake of honour and liberty. Wounded and tired as they were, they took that order
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: rather for a boon! They bowed low and entered the zenanas without uttering a
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: single word of protest. They were sure that there was no hope for this country at
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: all.
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
Then the Lady Principal with her two thousand students marched to the battle
field, and arriving there directed all the rays of the concentrated sunlight and heat
towards the enemy.
The heat and light were too much for them to bear. They all ran away panicstricken, not knowing in their bewilderment how to counteract that scorching heat.
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: When they fled away leaving their guns and other ammunitions of war, they were
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: burnt down by means of the same sun-heat. Since then no one has tried to invade
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
our country any more.
And since then your countrymen never tried to come out of the zenana?
Yes, they wanted to be free. Some of the police commissioners and district
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: magistrates sent word to the Queen to the effect that the military officers certainly
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: deserved to be imprisoned for their failure; but they never neglected their duty and
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: therefore they should not be punished and they prayed to be restored to their
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: respective offices.
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: Sultanas Dream
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: Page No - 11
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
Her Royal Highness sent them a circular letter intimating to them that if their
services should ever be needed they would be sent for, and that in the meanwhile
they should remain where they were. Now that they are accustomed to the purdah
system and have ceased to grumble at their seclusion, we call the system
"Mardana" instead of "zenana".
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
But how do you manage, I asked Sister Sara, to do without the police or
magistrates in case of theft or murder?
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
Since the "Mardana" system has been established, there has been no more crime
or sin; therefore we do not require a policeman to find out a culprit, nor do we
want a magistrate to try a criminal case.
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
That is very good, indeed. I suppose if there was any dishonest person, you could
very easily chastise her. As you gained a decisive victory without shedding a
single drop of blood, you could drive off crime and criminals too without much
difficulty!
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: Now, dear Sultana, will you sit here or come to my parlour? she asked me.
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
Your kitchen is not inferior to a queens boudoir! I replied with a pleasant smile,
but we must leave it now; for the gentlemen may be cursing me for keeping them
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
away from their duties in the kitchen so long. We both laughed heartily.
How my friends at home will be amused and amazed, when I go back and tell
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: them that in the far-off Ladyland, ladies rule over the country and control all social
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: matters, while gentlemen are kept in the Mardanas to mind babies, to cook and to
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: do all sorts of domestic work; and that cooking is so easy a thing that it is simply a
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
pleasure to cook!
Yes, tell them about all that you see here.
Please let me know, how you carry on land cultivation and how you plough the
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
land and do other hard manual work.
Our fields are tilled by means of electricity, which supplies motive power for
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: other hard work as well, and we employ it for our aerial conveyances too. We
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
have no rail road nor any paved streets here.
Therefore neither street nor railway accidents occur here, said I. Do not you ever
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
suffer from want of rainwater? I asked.
Never since the water balloon has been set up. You see the big balloon and
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: pipes attached thereto. By their aid we can draw as much rainwater as we require.
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: Sultanas Dream
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: Page No - 12
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: Nor do we ever suffer from flood or thunderstorms. We are all very busy making
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: nature yield as much as she can. We do not find time to quarrel with one another
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: as we never sit idle. Our noble Queen is exceedingly fond of botany; it is her
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
ambition to convert the whole country into one grand garden.
The idea is excellent. What is your chief food?
Fruits.
How do you keep your country cool in hot weather? We regard the rainfall in
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
summer as a blessing from heaven.
When the heat becomes unbearable, we sprinkle the ground with plentiful showers
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: drawn from the artificial fountains. And in cold weather we keep our room warm
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
with sun-heat.
She showed me her bathroom, the roof of which was removable. She could enjoy a
shower bath whenever she liked, by simply removing the roof (which was like the
lid of a box) and turning on the tap of the shower pipe.
You are a lucky people! ejaculated I. You know no want. What is your religion,
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
may I ask?
Our religion is based on Love and Truth. It is our religious duty to love one
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
another and to be absolutely truthful. If any person lies, she or he is....
Punished with death?
No, not with death. We do not take pleasure in killing a creature of God,
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: especially a human being. The liar is asked to leave this land for good and never to
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
come to it again.
Is an offender never forgiven?
Yes, if that person repents sincerely.
Are you not allowed to see any man, except your own relations?
No one except sacred relations.
Our circle of sacred relations is very limited; even first cousins are not sacred.
But ours is very large; a distant cousin is as sacred as a brother.



Sultanas Dream

Page No - 13

That is very good. I see purity itself reigns over your land. I should like to see the
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: good Queen, who is so sagacious and far-sighted and who has made all these
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
rules.
All right, said Sister Sara.
Then she screwed a couple of seats onto a square piece of plank. To this plank she
attached two smooth and well-polished balls. When I asked her what the balls
were for, she said they were hydrogen balls and they were used to overcome the
force of gravity. The balls were of different capacities to be used according to the
different weights desired to be overcome. She then fastened to the air-car two
wing-like blades, which, she said, were worked by electricity. After we were
comfortably seated she touched a knob and the blades began to whirl, moving
faster and faster every moment. At first we were raised to the height of about six
or seven feet and then off we flew. And before I could realize that we had
commenced moving, we reached the garden of the Queen.
My friend lowered the air-car by reversing the action of the machine, and when
the car touched the ground the machine was stopped and we got out.
I had seen from the air-car the Queen walking on a garden path with her little
daughter (who was four years old) and her maids of honour.
Halloo! You here! cried the Queen addressing Sister Sara. I was introduced to
Her Royal Highness and was received by her cordially without any ceremony.
I was very much delighted to make her acquaintance. In the course of the
conversation I had with her, the Queen told me that she had no objection to
permitting her subjects to trade with other countries. But, she continued, no trade
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: was possible with countries where the women were kept in the zenanas and so
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text: unable to come and trade with us. Men, we find, are rather of lower morals and so
title: Sultanaís Dream
author: Rokheya Shekhawat Hossein

text:
we do not like dealing with them. We do not covet other peoples land, we do not
fight for a piece of diamond though it may be a thousand-fold brighter than the
Koh-i-Noor, nor do we grudge a ruler his Peacock Throne. We dive deep into the
ocean of knowledge and try to find out the precious gems, which nature has kept
in store for us. We enjoy natures gifts as much as we can.
After taking leave of the Queen, I visited the famous universities, and was shown
some of their manufactories, laboratories and observatories.
After visiting the above places of interest we got again into the air-car, but as soon
as it began moving, I somehow slipped down and the fall startled me out of my



Sultanas Dream

Page No - 14

dream. And on opening my eyes, I found myself in my own bedroom still
lounging in the easy-chair!

text: CHAPTER 1. A Not Unnatural Enterprise
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: This is written from memory, unfortunately. If I could have brought with
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: me the material I so carefully prepared, this would be a very different
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: story. Whole books full of notes, carefully copied records, firsthand
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: descriptions, and the pictures--that's the worst loss. We had some
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: bird's-eyes of the cities and parks; a lot of lovely views of streets,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: of buildings, outside and in, and some of those gorgeous gardens, and,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: most important of all, of the women themselves.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Nobody will ever believe how they looked. Descriptions aren't any good
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: when it comes to women, and I never was good at descriptions anyhow. But
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: it's got to be done somehow; the rest of the world needs to know about
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: that country.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: I haven't said where it was for fear some self-appointed missionaries,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: or traders, or land-greedy expansionists, will take it upon themselves
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: to push in. They will not be wanted, I can tell them that, and will fare
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: worse than we did if they do find it.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: It began this way. There were three of us, classmates and friends--Terry
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: O. Nicholson (we used to call him the Old Nick, with good reason), Jeff
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Margrave, and I, Vandyck Jennings.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: We had known each other years and years, and in spite of our differences
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: we had a good deal in common. All of us were interested in science.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Terry was rich enough to do as he pleased. His great aim was
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: exploration. He used to make all kinds of a row because there was
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: nothing left to explore now, only patchwork and filling in, he said. He
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: filled in well enough--he had a lot of talents--great on mechanics and
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: electricity. Had all kinds of boats and motorcars, and was one of the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: best of our airmen.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: We never could have done the thing at all without Terry.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Jeff Margrave was born to be a poet, a botanist--or both--but his folks
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: persuaded him to be a doctor instead. He was a good one, for his age,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: but his real interest was in what he loved to call "the wonders of
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: science."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: As for me, sociology's my major. You have to back that up with a lot of
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: other sciences, of course. I'm interested in them all.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Terry was strong on facts--geography and meteorology and those; Jeff
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: could beat him any time on biology, and I didn't care what it was they
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: talked about, so long as it connected with human life, somehow. There
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: are few things that don't.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: We three had a chance to join a big scientific expedition. They needed
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: a doctor, and that gave Jeff an excuse for dropping his just opening
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: practice; they needed Terry's experience, his machine, and his money;
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: and as for me, I got in through Terry's influence.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: The expedition was up among the thousand tributaries and enormous
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: hinterland of a great river, up where the maps had to be made, savage
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: dialects studied, and all manner of strange flora and fauna expected.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: But this story is not about that expedition. That was only the merest
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: starter for ours.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: My interest was first roused by talk among our guides. I'm quick at
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: languages, know a good many, and pick them up readily. What with that
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: and a really good interpreter we took with us, I made out quite a few
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: legends and folk myths of these scattered tribes.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: And as we got farther and farther upstream, in a dark tangle of rivers,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: lakes, morasses, and dense forests, with here and there an unexpected
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: long spur running out from the big mountains beyond, I noticed that more
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: and more of these savages had a story about a strange and terrible Woman
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Land in the high distance.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Up yonder," "Over there," "Way up"--was all the direction they could
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: offer, but their legends all agreed on the main point--that there was
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: this strange country where no men lived--only women and girl children.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: None of them had ever seen it. It was dangerous, deadly, they said, for
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: any man to go there. But there were tales of long ago, when some brave
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: investigator had seen it--a Big Country, Big Houses, Plenty People--All
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Women.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Had no one else gone? Yes--a good many--but they never came back. It was
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: no place for men--of that they seemed sure.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: I told the boys about these stories, and they laughed at them. Naturally
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: I did myself. I knew the stuff that savage dreams are made of.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: But when we had reached our farthest point, just the day before we all
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: had to turn around and start for home again, as the best of expeditions
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: must in time, we three made a discovery.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: The main encampment was on a spit of land running out into the main
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: stream, or what we thought was the main stream. It had the same muddy
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: color we had been seeing for weeks past, the same taste.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: I happened to speak of that river to our last guide, a rather superior
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: fellow with quick, bright eyes.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: He told me that there was another river--"over there, short river, sweet
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: water, red and blue."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: I was interested in this and anxious to see if I had understood, so I
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: showed him a red and blue pencil I carried, and asked again.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Yes, he pointed to the river, and then to the southwestward.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "River--good water--red and blue."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Terry was close by and interested in the fellow's pointing.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "What does he say, Van?"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: I told him.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Terry blazed up at once.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Ask him how far it is."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: The man indicated a short journey; I judged about two hours, maybe
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: three.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Let's go," urged Terry. "Just us three. Maybe we can really find
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: something. May be cinnabar in it."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "May be indigo," Jeff suggested, with his lazy smile.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: It was early yet; we had just breakfasted; and leaving word that we'd
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: be back before night, we got away quietly, not wishing to be thought
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: too gullible if we failed, and secretly hoping to have some nice little
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: discovery all to ourselves.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: It was a long two hours, nearer three. I fancy the savage could have
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: done it alone much quicker. There was a desperate tangle of wood and
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: water and a swampy patch we never should have found our way across
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: alone. But there was one, and I could see Terry, with compass and
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: notebook, marking directions and trying to place landmarks.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: We came after a while to a sort of marshy lake, very big, so that the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: circling forest looked quite low and dim across it. Our guide told us
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: that boats could go from there to our camp--but "long way--all day."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: This water was somewhat clearer than that we had left, but we could not
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: judge well from the margin. We skirted it for another half hour or so,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: the ground growing firmer as we advanced, and presently we turned the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: corner of a wooded promontory and saw a quite different country--a
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: sudden view of mountains, steep and bare.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "One of those long easterly spurs," Terry said appraisingly. "May be
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: hundreds of miles from the range. They crop out like that."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Suddenly we left the lake and struck directly toward the cliffs. We
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: heard running water before we reached it, and the guide pointed proudly
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: to his river.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: It was short. We could see where it poured down a narrow vertical
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: cataract from an opening in the face of the cliff. It was sweet water.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: The guide drank eagerly and so did we.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "That's snow water," Terry announced. "Must come from way back in the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: hills."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: But as to being red and blue--it was greenish in tint. The guide seemed
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: not at all surprised. He hunted about a little and showed us a quiet
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: marginal pool where there were smears of red along the border; yes, and
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: of blue.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Terry got out his magnifying glass and squatted down to investigate.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Chemicals of some sort--I can't tell on the spot. Look to me like
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: dyestuffs. Let's get nearer," he urged, "up there by the fall."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: We scrambled along the steep banks and got close to the pool that foamed
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: and boiled beneath the falling water. Here we searched the border and
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: found traces of color beyond dispute. More--Jeff suddenly held up an
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: unlooked-for trophy.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: It was only a rag, a long, raveled fragment of cloth. But it was a
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: well-woven fabric, with a pattern, and of a clear scarlet that the water
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: had not faded. No savage tribe that we had heard of made such fabrics.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: The guide stood serenely on the bank, well pleased with our excitement.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "One day blue--one day red--one day green," he told us, and pulled from
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: his pouch another strip of bright-hued cloth.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Come down," he said, pointing to the cataract. "Woman Country--up
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: there."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Then we were interested. We had our rest and lunch right there and
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: pumped the man for further information. He could tell us only what the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: others had--a land of women--no men--babies, but all girls. No place for
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: men--dangerous. Some had gone to see--none had come back.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: I could see Terry's jaw set at that. No place for men? Dangerous? He
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: looked as if he might shin up the waterfall on the spot. But the guide
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: would not hear of going up, even if there had been any possible method
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: of scaling that sheer cliff, and we had to get back to our party before

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: night.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "They might stay if we told them," I suggested.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: But Terry stopped in his tracks. "Look here, fellows," he said. "This
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: is our find. Let's not tell those cocky old professors. Let's go on home
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: with 'em, and then come back--just us--have a little expedition of our
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: own."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: We looked at him, much impressed. There was something attractive to a
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: bunch of unattached young men in finding an undiscovered country of a
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: strictly Amazonian nature.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Of course we didn't believe the story--but yet!
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "There is no such cloth made by any of these local tribes," I announced,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: examining those rags with great care. "Somewhere up yonder they spin and
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: weave and dye--as well as we do."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "That would mean a considerable civilization, Van. There couldn't be
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Oh, well, I don't know. What's that old republic up in the Pyrenees

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: somewhere--Andorra? Precious few people know anything about that, and
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: it's been minding its own business for a thousand years. Then there's
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Montenegro--splendid little state--you could lose a dozen Montenegroes

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: up and down these great ranges."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: care and privacy on the voyage home. We discussed it after that, still
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: only among ourselves, while Terry was making his arrangements.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: He was hot about it. Lucky he had so much money--we might have had to

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: without any more notice than a snip in the society column.

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: previous experience stood him in good stead there. It was a very

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland

title: Herland

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: on our part. We had no weapons, and if we did try to do any damage, with
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: a chair, say, why five to one was too many for us, even if they were
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: women; that we had found out to our sorrow. It was not pleasant, having
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: them always around, but we soon got used to it.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "It's better than being physically restrained ourselves," Jeff
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: philosophically suggested when we were alone. "They've given us a
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: room--with no great possibility of escape--and personal liberty--heavily
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: chaperoned. It's better than we'd have been likely to get in a
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: man-country."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Man-Country! Do you really believe there are no men here, you innocent?
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Don't you know there must be?" demanded Terry.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Ye--es," Jeff agreed. "Of course--and yet--"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "And yet--what! Come, you obdurate sentimentalist--what are you thinking
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: about?"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "They may have some peculiar division of labor we've never heard of," I
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: suggested. "The men may live in separate towns, or they may have subdued
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: them--somehow--and keep them shut up. But there must be some."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "That last suggestion of yours is a nice one, Van," Terry protested.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Same as they've got us subdued and shut up! you make me shiver."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Well, figure it out for yourself, anyway you please. We saw plenty of
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: kids, the first day, and we've seen those girls--"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Real girls!" Terry agreed, in immense relief. "Glad you mentioned
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: 'em. I declare, if I thought there was nothing in the country but those
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: grenadiers I'd jump out the window."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Speaking of windows," I suggested, "let's examine ours."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: We looked out of all the windows. The blinds opened easily enough, and
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: there were no bars, but the prospect was not reassuring.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: This was not the pink-walled town we had so rashly entered the day
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: before. Our chamber was high up, in a projecting wing of a sort of
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: castle, built out on a steep spur of rock. Immediately below us were
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: gardens, fruitful and fragrant, but their high walls followed the edge
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: of the cliff which dropped sheer down, we could not see how far. The
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: distant sound of water suggested a river at the foot.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: We could look out east, west, and south. To the southeastward stretched
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: the open country, lying bright and fair in the morning light, but on
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: either side, and evidently behind, rose great mountains.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "This thing is a regular fortress--and no women built it, I can tell
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: you that," said Terry. We nodded agreeingly. "It's right up among the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: hills--they must have brought us a long way."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "We saw some kind of swift-moving vehicles the first day," Jeff reminded
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: us. "If they've got motors, they ARE civilized."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Civilized or not, we've got our work cut out for us to get away from
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: here. I don't propose to make a rope of bedclothes and try those walls
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: till I'm sure there is no better way."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: We all concurred on this point, and returned to our discussion as to the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: women.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Jeff continued thoughtful. "All the same, there's something funny about
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: it," he urged. "It isn't just that we don't see any men--but we don't
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: see any signs of them. The--the--reaction of these women is different
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: from any that I've ever met."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "There is something in what you say, Jeff," I agreed. "There is a
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: different--atmosphere."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "They don't seem to notice our being men," he went on. "They treat
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: us--well--just as they do one another. It's as if our being men was a
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: minor incident."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: I nodded. I'd noticed it myself. But Terry broke in rudely.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Fiddlesticks!" he said. "It's because of their advanced age. They're
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: all grandmas, I tell you--or ought to be. Great aunts, anyhow. Those
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: girls were girls all right, weren't they?"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Yes--" Jeff agreed, still slowly. "But they weren't afraid--they flew
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: up that tree and hid, like schoolboys caught out of bounds--not like shy
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: girls."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "And they ran like marathon winners--you'll admit that, Terry," he
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: added.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Terry was moody as the days passed. He seemed to mind our confinement
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: more than Jeff or I did; and he harped on Alima, and how near he'd come
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: to catching her. "If I had--" he would say, rather savagely, "we'd have
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: had a hostage and could have made terms."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: But Jeff was getting on excellent terms with his tutor, and even his
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: guards, and so was I. It interested me profoundly to note and study
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: the subtle difference between these women and other women, and try to
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: account for them. In the matter of personal appearance, there was a
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: great difference. They all wore short hair, some few inches at most;
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: some curly, some not; all light and clean and fresh-looking.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "If their hair was only long," Jeff would complain, "they would look so
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: much more feminine."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: I rather liked it myself, after I got used to it. Why we should so
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: admire "a woman's crown of hair" and not admire a Chinaman's queue is
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: hard to explain, except that we are so convinced that the long hair
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "belongs" to a woman. Whereas the "mane" in horses is on both, and in
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: lions, buffalos, and such creatures only on the male. But I did miss
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: it--at first.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Our time was quite pleasantly filled. We were free of the garden below
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: our windows, quite long in its irregular rambling shape, bordering the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: cliff. The walls were perfectly smooth and high, ending in the masonry
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: of the building; and as I studied the great stones I became convinced
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: that the whole structure was extremely old. It was built like the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: pre-Incan architecture in Peru, of enormous monoliths, fitted as closely
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: as mosaics.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "These folks have a history, that's sure," I told the others. "And SOME
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: time they were fighters--else why a fortress?"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: I said we were free of the garden, but not wholly alone in it. There
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: was always a string of those uncomfortably strong women sitting about,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: always one of them watching us even if the others were reading, playing
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: games, or busy at some kind of handiwork.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "When I see them knit," Terry said, "I can almost call them feminine."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "That doesn't prove anything," Jeff promptly replied. "Scotch shepherds
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: knit--always knitting."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "When we get out--" Terry stretched himself and looked at the far
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: peaks, "when we get out of this and get to where the real women are--the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: mothers, and the girls--"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Well, what'll we do then?" I asked, rather gloomily. "How do you know
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: we'll ever get out?"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: This was an unpleasant idea, which we unanimously considered, returning
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: with earnestness to our studies.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "If we are good boys and learn our lessons well," I suggested. "If we
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: are quiet and respectful and polite and they are not afraid of us--then
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: perhaps they will let us out. And anyway--when we do escape, it is of
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: immense importance that we know the language."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Personally, I was tremendously interested in that language, and seeing
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: they had books, was eager to get at them, to dig into their history, if
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: they had one.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: It was not hard to speak, smooth and pleasant to the ear, and so easy
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: to read and write that I marveled at it. They had an absolutely phonetic
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: system, the whole thing was as scientific as Esparanto yet bore all the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: marks of an old and rich civilization.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: We were free to study as much as we wished, and were not left merely to
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: wander in the garden for recreation but introduced to a great gymnasium,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: partly on the roof and partly in the story below. Here we learned real
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: respect for our tall guards. No change of costume was needed for this
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: work, save to lay off outer clothing. The first one was as perfect a
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: garment for exercise as need be devised, absolutely free to move in,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: and, I had to admit, much better-looking than our usual one.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Forty--over forty--some of 'em fifty, I bet--and look at 'em!" grumbled
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Terry in reluctant admiration.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: There were no spectacular acrobatics, such as only the young can
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: perform, but for all-around development they had a most excellent
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: system. A good deal of music went with it, with posture dancing and,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: sometimes, gravely beautiful processional performances.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Jeff was much impressed by it. We did not know then how small a part of
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: their physical culture methods this really was, but found it agreeable
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: to watch, and to take part in.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Oh yes, we took part all right! It wasn't absolutely compulsory, but we
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: thought it better to please.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Terry was the strongest of us, though I was wiry and had good staying
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: power, and Jeff was a great sprinter and hurdler, but I can tell you
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: those old ladies gave us cards and spades. They ran like deer, by which
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: I mean that they ran not as if it was a performance, but as if it was
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: their natural gait. We remembered those fleeting girls of our first
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: bright adventure, and concluded that it was.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: They leaped like deer, too, with a quick folding motion of the legs,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: drawn up and turned to one side with a sidelong twist of the body. I
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: remembered the sprawling spread-eagle way in which some of the fellows
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: used to come over the line--and tried to learn the trick. We did not
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: easily catch up with these experts, however.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Never thought I'd live to be bossed by a lot of elderly lady acrobats,"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Terry protested.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: They had games, too, a good many of them, but we found them rather
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: uninteresting at first. It was like two people playing solitaire to
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: see who would get it first; more like a race or a--a competitive
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: examination, than a real game with some fight in it.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: I philosophized a bit over this and told Terry it argued against their
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: having any men about. "There isn't a man-size game in the lot," I said.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "But they are interesting--I like them," Jeff objected, "and I'm sure
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: they are educational."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "I'm sick and tired of being educated," Terry protested. "Fancy going to
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: a dame school--at our age. I want to Get Out!"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: But we could not get out, and we were being educated swiftly. Our
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: special tutors rose rapidly in our esteem. They seemed of rather finer
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: quality than the guards, though all were on terms of easy friendliness.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Mine was named Somel, Jeff's Zava, and Terry's Moadine. We tried to
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: generalize from the names, those of the guards, and of our three girls,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: but got nowhere.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "They sound well enough, and they're mostly short, but there's no
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: similarity of termination--and no two alike. However, our acquaintance
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: is limited as yet."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: There were many things we meant to ask--as soon as we could talk well
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: enough. Better teaching I never saw. From morning to night there was
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Somel, always on call except between two and four; always pleasant with
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: a steady friendly kindness that I grew to enjoy very much. Jeff said
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Miss Zava--he would put on a title, though they apparently had none--was
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: a darling, that she reminded him of his Aunt Esther at home; but Terry
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: refused to be won, and rather jeered at his own companion, when we were
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: alone.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "I'm sick of it!" he protested. "Sick of the whole thing. Here we are
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: cooped up as helpless as a bunch of three-year-old orphans, and being
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: taught what they think is necessary--whether we like it or not. Confound
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: their old-maid impudence!"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Nevertheless we were taught. They brought in a raised map of their
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: country, beautifully made, and increased our knowledge of geographical
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: terms; but when we inquired for information as to the country outside,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: they smilingly shook their heads.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: They brought pictures, not only the engravings in the books but colored
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: studies of plants and trees and flowers and birds. They brought tools
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: and various small objects--we had plenty of "material" in our school.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: If it had not been for Terry we would have been much more contented, but
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: as the weeks ran into months he grew more and more irritable.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Don't act like a bear with a sore head," I begged him. "We're getting
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: on finely. Every day we can understand them better, and pretty soon we
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: can make a reasonable plea to be let out--"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "LET out!" he stormed. "LET out--like children kept after school. I want
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: to Get Out, and I'm going to. I want to find the men of this place and
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: fight!--or the girls--"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Guess it's the girls you're most interested in," Jeff commented. "What
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: are you going to fight WITH--your fists?"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Yes--or sticks and stones--I'd just like to!" And Terry squared off and
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: tapped Jeff softly on the jaw. "Just for instance," he said.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Anyhow," he went on, "we could get back to our machine and clear out."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "If it's there," I cautiously suggested.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Oh, don't croak, Van! If it isn't there, we'll find our way down
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: somehow--the boat's there, I guess."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: It was hard on Terry, so hard that he finally persuaded us to consider
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: a plan of escape. It was difficult, it was highly dangerous, but he
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: declared that he'd go alone if we wouldn't go with him, and of course we
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: couldn't think of that.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: It appeared he had made a pretty careful study of the environment. From
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: our end window that faced the point of the promontory we could get a
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: fair idea of the stretch of wall, and the drop below. Also from the roof
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: we could make out more, and even, in one place, glimpse a sort of path
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: below the wall.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "It's a question of three things," he said. "Ropes, agility, and not

text: being seen."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "That's the hardest part," I urged, still hoping to dissuade him. "One
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: or another pair of eyes is on us every minute except at night."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Therefore we must do it at night," he answered. "That's easy."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "We've got to think that if they catch us we may not be so well treated

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: afterward," said Jeff.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "That's the business risk we must take. I'm going--if I break my neck."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: There was no changing him.

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: There were plenty of strong ropes in the gymnasium--they seemed to love

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: to swing and climb on them--but we were never there by ourselves.

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: We should have to piece it out from our bedding, rugs, and garments, and
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: moreover, we should have to do it after we were shut in for the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: night, for every day the place was cleaned to perfection by two of our

text: guardians.
title: Herland

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: It seemed a crazy risk to take, but this was, in a way, Terry's

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: and break it without noise was not difficult, and broken glass will cut,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: though not as deftly as a pair of scissors.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: The broad moonlight streamed in through four of our windows--we had not

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: dared leave our lights on too long--and we worked hard and fast at our

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: task of destruction.
