text: "Mainly on yourselves," she replied.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Why do you keep us shut up so closely?"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Because we do not feel quite safe in allowing you at large where there
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: are so many young women."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Terry was really pleased at that. He had thought as much, inwardly; but
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: he pushed the question. "Why should you be afraid? We are gentlemen."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: She smiled that little smile again, and asked: "Are 'gentlemen' always
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: safe?"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "You surely do not think that any of us," he said it with a good deal of
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: emphasis on the "us," "would hurt your young girls?"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Oh no," she said quickly, in real surprise. "The danger is quite the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: other way. They might hurt you. If, by any accident, you did harm any
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: one of us, you would have to face a million mothers."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: He looked so amazed and outraged that Jeff and I laughed outright, but
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: she went on gently.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "I do not think you quite understand yet. You are but men, three men,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: in a country where the whole population are mothers--or are going to be.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Motherhood means to us something which I cannot yet discover in any
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: of the countries of which you tell us. You have spoken"--she turned to
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Jeff, "of Human Brotherhood as a great idea among you, but even that I
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: judge is far from a practical expression?"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Jeff nodded rather sadly. "Very far--" he said.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Here we have Human Motherhood--in full working use," she went on.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Nothing else except the literal sisterhood of our origin, and the far
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: higher and deeper union of our social growth.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "The children in this country are the one center and focus of all our
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: thoughts. Every step of our advance is always considered in its effect
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: on them--on the race. You see, we are MOTHERS," she repeated, as if in
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: that she had said it all.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "I don't see how that fact--which is shared by all women--constitutes
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: any risk to us," Terry persisted. "You mean they would defend their
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: children from attack. Of course. Any mothers would. But we are not
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: savages, my dear lady; we are not going to hurt any mother's child."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: They looked at one another and shook their heads a little, but
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Zava turned to Jeff and urged him to make us see--said he seemed to
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: understand more fully than we did. And he tried.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: I can see it now, or at least much more of it, but it has taken me a
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: long time, and a good deal of honest intellectual effort.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: What they call Motherhood was like this:
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: They began with a really high degree of social development, something
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: like that of Ancient Egypt or Greece. Then they suffered the loss of
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: everything masculine, and supposed at first that all human power and
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: safety had gone too. Then they developed this virgin birth capacity.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Then, since the prosperity of their children depended on it, the fullest
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: and subtlest coordination began to be practiced.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: I remember how long Terry balked at the evident unanimity of these
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: women--the most conspicuous feature of their whole culture. "It's
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: impossible!" he would insist. "Women cannot cooperate--it's against
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: nature."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: When we urged the obvious facts he would say: "Fiddlesticks!" or "Hang
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: your facts--I tell you it can't be done!" And we never succeeded in
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: shutting him up till Jeff dragged in the hymenoptera.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "'Go to the ant, thou sluggard'--and learn something," he said
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: triumphantly. "Don't they cooperate pretty well? You can't beat it. This
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: place is just like an enormous anthill--you know an anthill is nothing
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: but a nursery. And how about bees? Don't they manage to cooperate and
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: love one another? as that precious Constable had it. Just show me a
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: combination of male creatures, bird, bug, or beast, that works as well,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: will you? Or one of our masculine countries where the people work
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: together as well as they do here! I tell you, women are the natural
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: cooperators, not men!"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Terry had to learn a good many things he did not want to. To go back to
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: my little analysis of what happened:
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: They developed all this close inter-service in the interests of their
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: children. To do the best work they had to specialize, of course; the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: children needed spinners and weavers, farmers and gardeners, carpenters
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: and masons, as well as mothers.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Then came the filling up of the place. When a population multiplies
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: by five every thirty years it soon reaches the limits of a country,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: especially a small one like this. They very soon eliminated all the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: grazing cattle--sheep were the last to go, I believe. Also, they worked
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: out a system of intensive agriculture surpassing anything I ever heard
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: of, with the very forests all reset with fruit- or nut-bearing trees.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Do what they would, however, there soon came a time when they were
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: confronted with the problem of "the pressure of population" in an acute
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: form. There was really crowding, and with it, unavoidably, a decline in
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: standards.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: And how did those women meet it?
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Not by a "struggle for existence" which would result in an everlasting
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: writhing mass of underbred people trying to get ahead of one
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: another--some few on top, temporarily, many constantly crushed out
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: underneath, a hopeless substratum of paupers and degenerates, and no
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: serenity or peace for anyone, no possibility for really noble qualities
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: among the people at large.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Neither did they start off on predatory excursions to get more land from
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: somebody else, or to get more food from somebody else, to maintain their
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: struggling mass.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Not at all. They sat down in council together and thought it out. Very
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: clear, strong thinkers they were. They said: "With our best endeavors
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: this country will support about so many people, with the standard of
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: peace, comfort, health, beauty, and progress we demand. Very well. That
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: is all the people we will make."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: There you have it. You see, they were Mothers, not in our sense of
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: helpless involuntary fecundity, forced to fill and overfill the land,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: every land, and then see their children suffer, sin, and die, fighting
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: horribly with one another; but in the sense of Conscious Makers
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: of People. Mother-love with them was not a brute passion, a mere
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "instinct," a wholly personal feeling; it was--a religion.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: It included that limitless feeling of sisterhood, that wide unity in
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: service, which was so difficult for us to grasp. And it was National,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Racial, Human--oh, I don't know how to say it.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: We are used to seeing what we call "a mother" completely wrapped up in
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: her own pink bundle of fascinating babyhood, and taking but the faintest
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: theoretic interest in anybody else's bundle, to say nothing of the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: common needs of ALL the bundles. But these women were working all
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: together at the grandest of tasks--they were Making People--and they
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: made them well.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: There followed a period of "negative eugenics" which must have been an
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: appalling sacrifice. We are commonly willing to "lay down our lives" for
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: our country, but they had to forego motherhood for their country--and it
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: was precisely the hardest thing for them to do.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: When I got this far in my reading I went to Somel for more light. We
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: were as friendly by that time as I had ever been in my life with any
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: woman. A mighty comfortable soul she was, giving one the nice smooth
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: mother-feeling a man likes in a woman, and yet giving also the clear
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: intelligence and dependableness I used to assume to be masculine
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: qualities. We had talked volumes already.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "See here," said I. "Here was this dreadful period when they got far too
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: thick, and decided to limit the population. We have a lot of talk about
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: that among us, but your position is so different that I'd like to know a
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: little more about it.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "I understand that you make Motherhood the highest social service--a
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: sacrament, really; that it is only undertaken once, by the majority of
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: the population; that those held unfit are not allowed even that; and
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: that to be encouraged to bear more than one child is the very highest
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: reward and honor in the power of the state."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: (She interpolated here that the nearest approach to an aristocracy
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: they had was to come of a line of "Over Mothers"--those who had been so
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: honored.)
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "But what I do not understand, naturally, is how you prevent it. I
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: gathered that each woman had five. You have no tyrannical husbands to
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: hold in check--and you surely do not destroy the unborn--"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: The look of ghastly horror she gave me I shall never forget. She started
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: from her chair, pale, her eyes blazing.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Destroy the unborn--!" she said in a hard whisper. "Do men do that in
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: your country?"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Men!" I began to answer, rather hotly, and then saw the gulf before
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: me. None of us wanted these women to think that OUR women, of whom we
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: boasted so proudly, were in any way inferior to them. I am ashamed
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: to say that I equivocated. I told her of certain criminal types of
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: women--perverts, or crazy, who had been known to commit infanticide. I
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: told her, truly enough, that there was much in our land which was
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: open to criticism, but that I hated to dwell on our defects until they
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: understood us and our conditions better.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: And, making a wide detour, I scrambled back to my question of how they
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: limited the population.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: As for Somel, she seemed sorry, a little ashamed even, of her too
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: clearly expressed amazement. As I look back now, knowing them better, I
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: am more and more and more amazed as I appreciate the exquisite courtesy
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: with which they had received over and over again statements and
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: admissions on our part which must have revolted them to the soul.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: She explained to me, with sweet seriousness, that as I had supposed, at
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: first each woman bore five children; and that, in their eager desire
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: to build up a nation, they had gone on in that way for a few centuries,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: till they were confronted with the absolute need of a limit. This fact
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: was equally plain to all--all were equally interested.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: They were now as anxious to check their wonderful power as they had
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: been to develop it; and for some generations gave the matter their most
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: earnest thought and study.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "We were living on rations before we worked it out," she said. "But we
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: did work it out. You see, before a child comes to one of us there is a
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: period of utter exaltation--the whole being is uplifted and filled with
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: a concentrated desire for that child. We learned to look forward to that
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: period with the greatest caution. Often our young women, those to whom
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: motherhood had not yet come, would voluntarily defer it. When that deep
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: inner demand for a child began to be felt she would deliberately engage
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: in the most active work, physical and mental; and even more important,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: would solace her longing by the direct care and service of the babies we
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: already had."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: She paused. Her wise sweet face grew deeply, reverently tender.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "We soon grew to see that mother-love has more than one channel of
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: expression. I think the reason our children are so--so fully loved, by
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: all of us, is that we never--any of us--have enough of our own."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: This seemed to me infinitely pathetic, and I said so. "We have much that
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: is bitter and hard in our life at home," I told her, "but this seems to
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: me piteous beyond words--a whole nation of starving mothers!"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: But she smiled her deep contented smile, and said I quite misunderstood.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "We each go without a certain range of personal joy," she said, "but
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: remember--we each have a million children to love and serve--OUR
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: children."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: It was beyond me. To hear a lot of women talk about "our children"! But
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: I suppose that is the way the ants and bees would talk--do talk, maybe.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: That was what they did, anyhow.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: When a woman chose to be a mother, she allowed the child-longing to
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: grow within her till it worked its natural miracle. When she did not so
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: choose she put the whole thing out of her mind, and fed her heart with
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: the other babies.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Let me see--with us, children--minors, that is--constitute about
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: three-fifths of the population; with them only about one-third, or
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: less. And precious--! No sole heir to an empire's throne, no solitary
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: millionaire baby, no only child of middle-aged parents, could compare as
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: an idol with these Herland children.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: But before I start on that subject I must finish up that little analysis
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: I was trying to make.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: They did effectually and permanently limit the population in numbers, so
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: that the country furnished plenty for the fullest, richest life for all
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: of them: plenty of everything, including room, air, solitude even.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: And then they set to work to improve that population in quality--since
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: they were restricted in quantity. This they had been at work on,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: uninterruptedly, for some fifteen hundred years. Do you wonder they were
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: nice people?
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Physiology, hygiene, sanitation, physical culture--all that line of work
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: had been perfected long since. Sickness was almost wholly unknown among
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: them, so much so that a previously high development in what we call the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "science of medicine" had become practically a lost art. They were a
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: clean-bred, vigorous lot, having the best of care, the most perfect
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: living conditions always.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: When it came to psychology--there was no one thing which left us so
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: dumbfounded, so really awed, as the everyday working knowledge--and
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: practice--they had in this line. As we learned more and more of it, we
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: learned to appreciate the exquisite mastery with which we ourselves,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: strangers of alien race, of unknown opposite sex, had been understood
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: and provided for from the first.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: With this wide, deep, thorough knowledge, they had met and solved the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: problems of education in ways some of which I hope to make clear later.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Those nation-loved children of theirs compared with the average in our
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: country as the most perfectly cultivated, richly developed roses compare
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: with--tumbleweeds. Yet they did not SEEM "cultivated" at all--it had all
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: become a natural condition.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: And this people, steadily developing in mental capacity, in will power,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: in social devotion, had been playing with the arts and sciences--as
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: far as they knew them--for a good many centuries now with inevitable
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: success.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Into this quiet lovely land, among these wise, sweet, strong women, we,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: in our easy assumption of superiority, had suddenly arrived; and now,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: tamed and trained to a degree they considered safe, we were at last
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: quilted with pockets. They were most ingeniously arranged, so as to be

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: convenient to the hand and not inconvenient to the body, and were so
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: placed as at once to strengthen the garment and add decorative lines of
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: stitching.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: In this, as in so many other points we had now to observe, there was
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: shown the action of a practical intelligence, coupled with fine artistic
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: feeling, and, apparently, untrammeled by any injurious influences.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Our first step of comparative freedom was a personally conducted tour of
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: the country. No pentagonal bodyguard now! Only our special tutors,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: and we got on famously with them. Jeff said he loved Zava like an
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: aunt--"only jollier than any aunt I ever saw"; Somel and I were as
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: chummy as could be--the best of friends; but it was funny to watch Terry
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: and Moadine. She was patient with him, and courteous, but it was like
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: the patience and courtesy of some great man, say a skilled, experienced
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: diplomat, with a schoolgirl. Her grave acquiescence with his most
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: preposterous expression of feeling; her genial laughter, not only
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: with, but, I often felt, at him--though impeccably polite; her
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: innocent questions, which almost invariably led him to say more than he
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: intended--Jeff and I found it all amusing to watch.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: He never seemed to recognize that quiet background of superiority. When
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: she dropped an argument he always thought he had silenced her; when she
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: laughed he thought it tribute to his wit.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: I hated to admit to myself how much Terry had sunk in my esteem. Jeff
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: felt it too, I am sure; but neither of us admitted it to the other.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: At home we had measured him with other men, and, though we knew his
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: failings, he was by no means an unusual type. We knew his virtues too,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: and they had always seemed more prominent than the faults. Measured
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: among women--our women at home, I mean--he had always stood high. He
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: was visibly popular. Even where his habits were known, there was no
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: discrimination against him; in some cases his reputation for what was
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: felicitously termed "gaiety" seemed a special charm.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: But here, against the calm wisdom and quiet restrained humor of these
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: women, with only that blessed Jeff and my inconspicuous self to compare
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: with, Terry did stand out rather strong.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: As "a man among men," he didn't; as a man among--I shall have to say,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "females," he didn't; his intense masculinity seemed only fit complement
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: to their intense femininity. But here he was all out of drawing.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Moadine was a big woman, with a balanced strength that seldom showed.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Her eye was as quietly watchful as a fencer's. She maintained a pleasant
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: relation with her charge, but I doubt if many, even in that country,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: could have done as well.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: He called her "Maud," amongst ourselves, and said she was "a good old
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: soul, but a little slow"; wherein he was quite wrong. Needless to
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: say, he called Jeff's teacher "Java," and sometimes "Mocha," or plain
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Coffee"; when specially mischievous, "Chicory," and even "Postum." But
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Somel rather escaped this form of humor, save for a rather forced "Some
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: 'ell."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Don't you people have but one name?" he asked one day, after we
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: had been introduced to a whole group of them, all with pleasant,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: few-syllabled strange names, like the ones we knew.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Oh yes," Moadine told him. "A good many of us have another, as we get
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: on in life--a descriptive one. That is the name we earn. Sometimes even
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: that is changed, or added to, in an unusually rich life. Such as our
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: present Land Mother--what you call president or king, I believe. She
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: was called Mera, even as a child; that means 'thinker.' Later there
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: was added Du--Du-Mera--the wise thinker, and now we all know her as
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: O-du-mera--great and wise thinker. You shall meet her."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "No surnames at all then?" pursued Terry, with his somewhat patronizing
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: air. "No family name?"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Why no," she said. "Why should we? We are all descended from a common
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: source--all one 'family' in reality. You see, our comparatively brief
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: and limited history gives us that advantage at least."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "But does not each mother want her own child to bear her name?" I asked.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "No--why should she? The child has its own."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Why for--for identification--so people will know whose child she is."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "We keep the most careful records," said Somel. "Each one of us has our
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: exact line of descent all the way back to our dear First Mother. There
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: are many reasons for doing that. But as to everyone knowing which child
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: belongs to which mother--why should she?"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Here, as in so many other instances, we were led to feel the difference
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: between the purely maternal and the paternal attitude of mind. The
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: element of personal pride seemed strangely lacking.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "How about your other works?" asked Jeff. "Don't you sign your names to
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: them--books and statues and so on?"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Yes, surely, we are all glad and proud to. Not only books and statues,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: but all kinds of work. You will find little names on the houses, on the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: furniture, on the dishes sometimes. Because otherwise one is likely to
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: forget, and we want to know to whom to be grateful."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "You speak as if it were done for the convenience of the consumer--not
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: the pride of the producer," I suggested.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "It's both," said Somel. "We have pride enough in our work."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Then why not in your children?" urged Jeff.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "But we have! We're magnificently proud of them," she insisted.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Then why not sign 'em?" said Terry triumphantly.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Moadine turned to him with her slightly quizzical smile. "Because the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: finished product is not a private one. When they are babies, we do speak
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: of them, at times, as 'Essa's Lato,' or 'Novine's Amel'; but that is
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: merely descriptive and conversational. In the records, of course,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: the child stands in her own line of mothers; but in dealing with it
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: personally it is Lato, or Amel, without dragging in its ancestors."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "But have you names enough to give a new one to each child?"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Assuredly we have, for each living generation."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Then they asked about our methods, and found first that "we" did so and
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: so, and then that other nations did differently. Upon which they wanted
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: to know which method has been proved best--and we had to admit that
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: so far as we knew there had been no attempt at comparison, each people
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: pursuing its own custom in the fond conviction of superiority, and
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: either despising or quite ignoring the others.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: With these women the most salient quality in all their institutions was
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: reasonableness. When I dug into the records to follow out any line of
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: development, that was the most astonishing thing--the conscious effort
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: to make it better.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: They had early observed the value of certain improvements, had easily
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: inferred that there was room for more, and took the greatest pains to
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: develop two kinds of minds--the critic and inventor. Those who showed
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: an early tendency to observe, to discriminate, to suggest, were given
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: special training for that function; and some of their highest officials
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: spent their time in the most careful study of one or another branch of
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: work, with a view to its further improvement.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: In each generation there was sure to arrive some new mind to detect
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: faults and show need of alterations; and the whole corps of inventors
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: was at hand to apply their special faculty at the point criticized, and
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: offer suggestions.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: We had learned by this time not to open a discussion on any of their
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: characteristics without first priming ourselves to answer questions
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: about our own methods; so I kept rather quiet on this matter of
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: conscious improvement. We were not prepared to show our way was better.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: There was growing in our minds, at least in Jeff's and mine, a
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: keen appreciation of the advantages of this strange country and its
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: management. Terry remained critical. We laid most of it to his nerves.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: He certainly was irritable.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: The most conspicuous feature of the whole land was the perfection of
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: its food supply. We had begun to notice from that very first walk in the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: forest, the first partial view from our 'plane. Now we were taken to see
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: this mighty garden, and shown its methods of culture.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: The country was about the size of Holland, some ten or twelve
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: thousand square miles. One could lose a good many Hollands along the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: forest-smothered flanks of those mighty mountains. They had a population
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: of about three million--not a large one, but quality is something. Three
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: million is quite enough to allow for considerable variation, and these
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: people varied more widely than we could at first account for.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Terry had insisted that if they were parthenogenetic they'd be as alike
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: as so many ants or aphids; he urged their visible differences as proof
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: that there must be men--somewhere.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: But when we asked them, in our later, more intimate conversations, how
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: they accounted for so much divergence without cross-fertilization,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: they attributed it partly to the careful education, which followed each
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: slight tendency to differ, and partly to the law of mutation. This they
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: had found in their work with plants, and fully proven in their own case.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Physically they were more alike than we, as they lacked all morbid or
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: excessive types. They were tall, strong, healthy, and beautiful as a
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: race, but differed individually in a wide range of feature, coloring,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: and expression.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "But surely the most important growth is in mind--and in the things we
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: make," urged Somel. "Do you find your physical variation accompanied by
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: a proportionate variation in ideas, feelings, and products? Or, among
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: people who look more alike, do you find their internal life and their
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: work as similar?"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: We were rather doubtful on this point, and inclined to hold that there
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: was more chance of improvement in greater physical variation.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "It certainly should be," Zava admitted. "We have always thought it a
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: grave initial misfortune to have lost half our little world. Perhaps
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: that is one reason why we have so striven for conscious improvement."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "But acquired traits are not transmissible," Terry declared. "Weissman
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: has proved that."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: They never disputed our absolute statements, only made notes of them.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "If that is so, then our improvement must be due either to mutation, or
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: solely to education," she gravely pursued. "We certainly have improved.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: It may be that all these higher qualities were latent in the original
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: mother, that careful education is bringing them out, and that our
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: personal differences depend on slight variations in prenatal condition."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "I think it is more in your accumulated culture," Jeff suggested. "And
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: in the amazing psychic growth you have made. We know very little about
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: methods of real soul culture--and you seem to know a great deal."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Be that as it might, they certainly presented a higher level of active
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: intelligence, and of behavior, than we had so far really grasped. Having
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: known in our lives several people who showed the same delicate courtesy
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: and were equally pleasant to live with, at least when they wore their
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "company manners," we had assumed that our companions were a carefully
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: chosen few. Later we were more and more impressed that all this gentle
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: breeding was breeding; that they were born to it, reared in it, that it
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: was as natural and universal with them as the gentleness of doves or the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: alleged wisdom of serpents.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: As for the intelligence, I confess that this was the most impressive
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: and, to me, most mortifying, of any single feature of Herland. We soon
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: ceased to comment on this or other matters which to them were such
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: obvious commonplaces as to call forth embarrassing questions about our
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: own conditions.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: This was nowhere better shown than in that matter of food supply, which
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: I will now attempt to describe.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Having improved their agriculture to the highest point, and carefully
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: estimated the number of persons who could comfortably live on their
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: square miles; having then limited their population to that number, one
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: would think that was all there was to be done. But they had not thought
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: so. To them the country was a unit--it was theirs. They themselves were
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: a unit, a conscious group; they thought in terms of the community. As
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: such, their time-sense was not limited to the hopes and ambitions of an
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: individual life. Therefore, they habitually considered and carried out
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: plans for improvement which might cover centuries.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: I had never seen, had scarcely imagined, human beings undertaking such
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: a work as the deliberate replanting of an entire forest area with
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: different kinds of trees. Yet this seemed to them the simplest common
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: sense, like a man's plowing up an inferior lawn and reseeding it. Now
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: every tree bore fruit--edible fruit, that is. In the case of one
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: tree, in which they took especial pride, it had originally no fruit at
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: all--that is, none humanly edible--yet was so beautiful that they wished
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: to keep it. For nine hundred years they had experimented, and now
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: showed us this particularly lovely graceful tree, with a profuse crop of
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: nutritious seeds.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: They had early decided that trees were the best food plants, requiring
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: far less labor in tilling the soil, and bearing a larger amount of food
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: for the same ground space; also doing much to preserve and enrich the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: soil.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Due regard had been paid to seasonable crops, and their fruit and nuts,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: grains and berries, kept on almost the year through.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: On the higher part of the country, near the backing wall of mountains,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: they had a real winter with snow. Toward the south-eastern point, where
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: there was a large valley with a lake whose outlet was subterranean, the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: climate was like that of California, and citrus fruits, figs, and olives
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: grew abundantly.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: What impressed me particularly was their scheme of fertilization. Here
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: was this little shut-in piece of land where one would have thought an
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: ordinary people would have been starved out long ago or reduced to an
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: annual struggle for life. These careful culturists had worked out a
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: perfect scheme of refeeding the soil with all that came out of it. All
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: the scraps and leavings of their food, plant waste from lumber work or
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: textile industry, all the solid matter from the sewage, properly treated
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: and combined--everything which came from the earth went back to it.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: The practical result was like that in any healthy forest; an
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: increasingly valuable soil was being built, instead of the progressive
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: impoverishment so often seen in the rest of the world.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: When this first burst upon us we made such approving comments that they
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: were surprised that such obvious common sense should be praised; asked
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: what our methods were; and we had some difficulty in--well, in
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: diverting them, by referring to the extent of our own land, and
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: the--admitted--carelessness with which we had skimmed the cream of it.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: At least we thought we had diverted them. Later I found that besides
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: keeping a careful and accurate account of all we told them, they had a
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: sort of skeleton chart, on which the things we said and the things we
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: palpably avoided saying were all set down and studied. It really was
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: child's play for those profound educators to work out a painfully
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: accurate estimate of our conditions--in some lines. When a given line of
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: observation seemed to lead to some very dreadful inference they always
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: gave us the benefit of the doubt, leaving it open to further knowledge.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Some of the things we had grown to accept as perfectly natural, or
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: as belonging to our human limitations, they literally could not have
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: believed; and, as I have said, we had all of us joined in a tacit
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: endeavor to conceal much of the social status at home.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Confound their grandmotherly minds!" Terry said. "Of course they can't
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: understand a Man's World! They aren't human--they're just a pack of
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Fe-Fe-Females!" This was after he had to admit their parthenogenesis.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "I wish our grandfatherly minds had managed as well," said Jeff. "Do you
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: really think it's to our credit that we have muddled along with all our
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: poverty and disease and the like? They have peace and plenty, wealth and
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: beauty, goodness and intellect. Pretty good people, I think!"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "You'll find they have their faults too," Terry insisted; and partly in
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: self-defense, we all three began to look for those faults of theirs.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: We had been very strong on this subject before we got there--in those
title: Herland
