author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: up the ascending line, they had this dominant thought of building up a
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: great race through the children.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: All the surrendering devotion our women have put into their private
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: families, these women put into their country and race. All the loyalty
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: and service men expect of wives, they gave, not singly to men, but
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: collectively to one another.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: And the mother instinct, with us so painfully intense, so thwarted by
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: conditions, so concentrated in personal devotion to a few, so bitterly
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: hurt by death, disease, or barrenness, and even by the mere growth
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: of the children, leaving the mother alone in her empty nest--all this
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: feeling with them flowed out in a strong, wide current, unbroken through
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: the generations, deepening and widening through the years, including
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: every child in all the land.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: With their united power and wisdom, they had studied and overcome the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "diseases of childhood"--their children had none.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: They had faced the problems of education and so solved them that their
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: children grew up as naturally as young trees; learning through every
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: sense; taught continuously but unconsciously--never knowing they were
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: being educated.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: In fact, they did not use the word as we do. Their idea of education was
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: the special training they took, when half grown up, under experts. Then
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: the eager young minds fairly flung themselves on their chosen subjects,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: and acquired with an ease, a breadth, a grasp, at which I never ceased
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: to wonder.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: But the babies and little children never felt the pressure of that
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "forcible feeding" of the mind that we call "education." Of this, more
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: later.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: CHAPTER 9. Our Relations and Theirs
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: What I'm trying to show here is that with these women the whole
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: relationship of life counted in a glad, eager growing-up to join the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: ranks of workers in the line best loved; a deep, tender reverence for
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: one's own mother--too deep for them to speak of freely--and beyond that,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: the whole, free, wide range of sisterhood, the splendid service of the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: country, and friendships.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: To these women we came, filled with the ideas, convictions, traditions,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: of our culture, and undertook to rouse in them the emotions which--to
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: us--seemed proper.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: However much, or little, of true sex-feeling there was between us, it
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: phrased itself in their minds in terms of friendship, the one purely
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: personal love they knew, and of ultimate parentage. Visibly we were not
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: mothers, nor children, nor compatriots; so, if they loved us, we must be
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: friends.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: That we should pair off together in our courting days was natural to
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: them; that we three should remain much together, as they did themselves,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: was also natural. We had as yet no work, so we hung about them in their
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: forest tasks; that was natural, too.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: But when we began to talk about each couple having "homes" of our own,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: they could not understand it.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Our work takes us all around the country," explained Celis. "We cannot
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: live in one place all the time."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "We are together now," urged Alima, looking proudly at Terry's stalwart
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: nearness. (This was one of the times when they were "on," though
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: presently "off" again.)
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "It's not the same thing at all," he insisted. "A man wants a home of
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: his own, with his wife and family in it."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Staying in it? All the time?" asked Ellador. "Not imprisoned, surely!"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Of course not! Living there--naturally," he answered.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "What does she do there--all the time?" Alima demanded. "What is her
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: work?"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Then Terry patiently explained again that our women did not work--with
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: reservations.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "But what do they do--if they have no work?" she persisted.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "They take care of the home--and the children."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "At the same time?" asked Ellador.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Why yes. The children play about, and the mother has charge of it all.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: There are servants, of course."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: It seemed so obvious, so natural to Terry, that he always grew
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: impatient; but the girls were honestly anxious to understand.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "How many children do your women have?" Alima had her notebook out now,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: and a rather firm set of lip. Terry began to dodge.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "There is no set number, my dear," he explained. "Some have more, some
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: have less."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Some have none at all," I put in mischievously.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: They pounced on this admission and soon wrung from us the general fact
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: that those women who had the most children had the least servants, and
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: those who had the most servants had the least children.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "There!" triumphed Alima. "One or two or no children, and three or four
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: servants. Now what do those women DO?"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: We explained as best we might. We talked of "social duties,"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: disingenuously banking on their not interpreting the words as we did; we
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: talked of hospitality, entertainment, and various "interests." All the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: time we knew that to these large-minded women whose whole mental outlook
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: was so collective, the limitations of a wholly personal life were
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: inconceivable.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "We cannot really understand it," Ellador concluded. "We are only half
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: a people. We have our woman-ways and they have their man-ways and their
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: both-ways. We have worked out a system of living which is, of course,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: limited. They must have a broader, richer, better one. I should like to
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: see it."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "You shall, dearest," I whispered.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "There's nothing to smoke," complained Terry. He was in the midst of a
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: prolonged quarrel with Alima, and needed a sedative. "There's nothing to
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: drink. These blessed women have no pleasant vices. I wish we could get
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: out of here!"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: This wish was vain. We were always under a certain degree of
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: watchfulness. When Terry burst forth to tramp the streets at night he
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: always found a "Colonel" here or there; and when, on an occasion of
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: fierce though temporary despair, he had plunged to the cliff edge with
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: some vague view to escape, he found several of them close by. We were
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: free--but there was a string to it.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "They've no unpleasant ones, either," Jeff reminded him.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Wish they had!" Terry persisted. "They've neither the vices of men, nor
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: the virtues of women--they're neuters!"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "You know better than that. Don't talk nonsense," said I, severely.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: I was thinking of Ellador's eyes when they gave me a certain look, a
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: look she did not at all realize.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Jeff was equally incensed. "I don't know what 'virtues of women' you
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: miss. Seems to me they have all of them."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "They've no modesty," snapped Terry. "No patience, no submissiveness,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: none of that natural yielding which is woman's greatest charm."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: I shook my head pityingly. "Go and apologize and make friends again,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Terry. You've got a grouch, that's all. These women have the virtue
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: of humanity, with less of its faults than any folks I ever saw. As for
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: patience--they'd have pitched us over the cliffs the first day we lit
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: among 'em, if they hadn't that."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "There are no--distractions," he grumbled. "Nowhere a man can go and cut
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: loose a bit. It's an everlasting parlor and nursery."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "And workshop," I added. "And school, and office, and laboratory, and
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: studio, and theater, and--home."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "HOME!" he sneered. "There isn't a home in the whole pitiful place."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "There isn't anything else, and you know it," Jeff retorted hotly. "I
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: never saw, I never dreamed of, such universal peace and good will and
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: mutual affection."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Oh, well, of course, if you like a perpetual Sunday school, it's all
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: very well. But I like Something Doing. Here it's all done."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: There was something to this criticism. The years of pioneering lay far
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: behind them. Theirs was a civilization in which the initial difficulties
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: had long since been overcome. The untroubled peace, the unmeasured
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: plenty, the steady health, the large good will and smooth management
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: which ordered everything, left nothing to overcome. It was like a
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: pleasant family in an old established, perfectly run country place.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: I liked it because of my eager and continued interest in the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: sociological achievements involved. Jeff liked it as he would have liked
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: such a family and such a place anywhere.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Terry did not like it because he found nothing to oppose, to struggle
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: with, to conquer.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Life is a struggle, has to be," he insisted. "If there is no struggle,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: there is no life--that's all."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "You're talking nonsense--masculine nonsense," the peaceful Jeff
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: replied. He was certainly a warm defender of Herland. "Ants don't raise
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: their myriads by a struggle, do they? Or the bees?"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Oh, if you go back to insects--and want to live in an anthill--! I tell
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: you the higher grades of life are reached only through struggle--combat.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: There's no Drama here. Look at their plays! They make me sick."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: He rather had us there. The drama of the country was--to our
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: taste--rather flat. You see, they lacked the sex motive and, with it,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: jealousy. They had no interplay of warring nations, no aristocracy and
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: its ambitions, no wealth and poverty opposition.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: I see I have said little about the economics of the place; it should
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: have come before, but I'll go on about the drama now.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: They had their own kind. There was a most impressive array of pageantry,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: of processions, a sort of grand ritual, with their arts and their
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: religion broadly blended. The very babies joined in it. To see one of
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: their great annual festivals, with the massed and marching stateliness
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: of those great mothers, the young women brave and noble, beautiful and
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: strong; and then the children, taking part as naturally as ours would
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: frolic round a Christmas tree--it was overpowering in the impression of
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: joyous, triumphant life.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: They had begun at a period when the drama, the dance, music, religion,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: and education were all very close together; and instead of developing
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: them in detached lines, they had kept the connection. Let me try again
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: to give, if I can, a faint sense of the difference in the life view--the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: background and basis on which their culture rested.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Ellador told me a lot about it. She took me to see the children, the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: growing girls, the special teachers. She picked out books for me to
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: read. She always seemed to understand just what I wanted to know, and
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: how to give it to me.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: While Terry and Alima struck sparks and parted--he always madly drawn
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: to her and she to him--she must have been, or she'd never have stood the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: way he behaved--Ellador and I had already a deep, restful feeling, as
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: if we'd always had one another. Jeff and Celis were happy; there was no
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: question of that; but it didn't seem to me as if they had the good times
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: we did.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Well, here is the Herland child facing life--as Ellador tried to show
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: it to me. From the first memory, they knew Peace, Beauty, Order, Safety,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Love, Wisdom, Justice, Patience, and Plenty. By "plenty" I mean that the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: babies grew up in an environment which met their needs, just as young
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: fawns might grow up in dewy forest glades and brook-fed meadows. And
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: they enjoyed it as frankly and utterly as the fawns would.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: They found themselves in a big bright lovely world, full of the most
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: interesting and enchanting things to learn about and to do. The people
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: everywhere were friendly and polite. No Herland child ever met the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: overbearing rudeness we so commonly show to children. They were People,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: too, from the first; the most precious part of the nation.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: In each step of the rich experience of living, they found the instance
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: they were studying widen out into contact with an endless range of
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: common interests. The things they learned were RELATED, from the first;
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: related to one another, and to the national prosperity.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "It was a butterfly that made me a forester," said Ellador. "I was about
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: eleven years old, and I found a big purple-and-green butterfly on a low
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: flower. I caught it, very carefully, by the closed wings, as I had been
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: told to do, and carried it to the nearest insect teacher"--I made a note
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: there to ask her what on earth an insect teacher was--"to ask her its
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: name. She took it from me with a little cry of delight. 'Oh, you blessed
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: child,' she said. 'Do you like obernuts?' Of course I liked obernuts,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: and said so. It is our best food-nut, you know. 'This is a female of the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: obernut moth,' she told me. 'They are almost gone. We have been trying
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: to exterminate them for centuries. If you had not caught this one, it
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: might have laid eggs enough to raise worms enough to destroy thousands
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: of our nut trees--thousands of bushels of nuts--and make years and years
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: of trouble for us.'
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Everybody congratulated me. The children all over the country were told
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: to watch for that moth, if there were any more. I was shown the history
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: of the creature, and an account of the damage it used to do and of how
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: long and hard our foremothers had worked to save that tree for us. I
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: grew a foot, it seemed to me, and determined then and there to be a
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: forester."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: This is but an instance; she showed me many. The big difference was that
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: whereas our children grow up in private homes and families, with every
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: effort made to protect and seclude them from a dangerous world, here
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: they grew up in a wide, friendly world, and knew it for theirs, from the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: first.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Their child-literature was a wonderful thing. I could have spent years
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: following the delicate subtleties, the smooth simplicities with which
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: they had bent that great art to the service of the child mind.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: We have two life cycles: the man's and the woman's. To the man there is
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: growth, struggle, conquest, the establishment of his family, and as much
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: further success in gain or ambition as he can achieve.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: To the woman, growth, the securing of a husband, the subordinate
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: activities of family life, and afterward such "social" or charitable
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: interests as her position allows.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Here was but one cycle, and that a large one.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: The child entered upon a broad open field of life, in which motherhood
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: was the one great personal contribution to the national life, and all
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: the rest the individual share in their common activities. Every girl I
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: talked to, at any age above babyhood, had her cheerful determination as
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: to what she was going to be when she grew up.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: What Terry meant by saying they had no "modesty" was that this great
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: life-view had no shady places; they had a high sense of personal
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: decorum, but no shame--no knowledge of anything to be ashamed of.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Even their shortcomings and misdeeds in childhood never were presented
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: to them as sins; merely as errors and misplays--as in a game. Some of
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: them, who were palpably less agreeable than others or who had a real
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: weakness or fault, were treated with cheerful allowance, as a friendly
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: group at whist would treat a poor player.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Their religion, you see, was maternal; and their ethics, based on the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: full perception of evolution, showed the principle of growth and the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: beauty of wise culture. They had no theory of the essential opposition
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: of good and evil; life to them was growth; their pleasure was in
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: growing, and their duty also.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: With this background, with their sublimated mother-love, expressed in
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: terms of widest social activity, every phase of their work was modified
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: by its effect on the national growth. The language itself they had
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: deliberately clarified, simplified, made easy and beautiful, for the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: sake of the children.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: This seemed to us a wholly incredible thing: first, that any nation
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: should have the foresight, the strength, and the persistence to plan
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: and fulfill such a task; and second, that women should have had so much

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Our theory is this," she went on carefully. "Here is a young human
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: being. The mind is as natural a thing as the body, a thing that grows,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: a thing to use and enjoy. We seek to nourish, to stimulate, to exercise

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: the mind of a child as we do the body. There are the two main divisions
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: in education--you have those of course?--the things it is necessary to
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: know, and the things it is necessary to do."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "To do? Mental exercises, you mean?"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Yes. Our general plan is this: In the matter of feeding the mind,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: of furnishing information, we use our best powers to meet the natural
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: appetite of a healthy young brain; not to overfeed it, to provide such
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: amount and variety of impressions as seem most welcome to each child.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: That is the easiest part. The other division is in arranging a properly
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: graduated series of exercises which will best develop each mind; the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: some of us have. You do this also, do you not?"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Yes. When one settles too close in one kind of work there is a tendency
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: learning, always."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "What do you study?"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "As much as we know of the different sciences. We have, within our
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: limits, a good deal of knowledge of anatomy, physiology, nutrition--all

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: that pertains to a full and beautiful personal life. We have our botany

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "You put psychology with history--not with personal life?"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Of course. It is ours; it is among and between us, and it changes with
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: the succeeding and improving generations. We are at work, slowly and
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: you find it so in your country?"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: This I evaded flatly. I remembered the cheerless claim that the human
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland

text: Power, to the River of Life pouring through them, which made them the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: bearers of the very Spirit of God.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Of all this I learned more and more--from their books, from talk,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: especially from Ellador. She was at first, for a brief moment, envious
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: of her friend--a thought she put away from her at once and forever.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "It is better," she said to me. "It is much better that it has not come
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: to me yet--to us, that is. For if I am to go with you to your country,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: we may have 'adventures by sea and land,' as you say [and as in truth we
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: did], and it might not be at all safe for a baby. So we won't try again,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: dear, till it is safe--will we?"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: This was a hard saying for a very loving husband.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Unless," she went on, "if one is coming, you will leave me behind. You
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: can come back, you know--and I shall have the child."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Then that deep ancient chill of male jealousy of even his own progeny
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: touched my heart.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "I'd rather have you, Ellador, than all the children in the world. I'd
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: rather have you with me--on your own terms--than not to have you."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: This was a very stupid saying. Of course I would! For if she wasn't
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: there I should want all of her and have none of her. But if she went
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: along as a sort of sublimated sister--only much closer and warmer than
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: that, really--why I should have all of her but that one thing. And I
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: was beginning to find that Ellador's friendship, Ellador's comradeship,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Ellador's sisterly affection, Ellador's perfectly sincere love--none
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: the less deep that she held it back on a definite line of reserve--were
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: enough to live on very happily.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: I find it quite beyond me to describe what this woman was to me. We talk
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: fine things about women, but in our hearts we know that they are very
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: limited beings--most of them. We honor them for their functional powers,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: even while we dishonor them by our use of it; we honor them for their
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: carefully enforced virtue, even while we show by our own conduct how
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: little we think of that virtue; we value them, sincerely, for the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: perverted maternal activities which make our wives the most comfortable
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: of servants, bound to us for life with the wages wholly at our own
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: decision, their whole business, outside of the temporary duties of such
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: motherhood as they may achieve, to meet our needs in every way. Oh, we
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: value them, all right, "in their place," which place is the home, where
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: they perform that mixture of duties so ably described by Mrs. Josephine
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Dodge Daskam Bacon, in which the services of "a mistress" are carefully
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: specified. She is a very clear writer, Mrs. J. D. D. Bacon, and
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: understands her subject--from her own point of view. But--that
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: combination of industries, while convenient, and in a way economical,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: does not arouse the kind of emotion commanded by the women of Herland.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: These were women one had to love "up," very high up, instead of down.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: They were not pets. They were not servants. They were not timid,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: inexperienced, weak.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: After I got over the jar to my pride (which Jeff, I truly think, never
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: felt--he was a born worshipper, and which Terry never got over--he
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: was quite clear in his ideas of "the position of women"), I found that
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: loving "up" was a very good sensation after all. It gave me a queer
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: feeling, way down deep, as of the stirring of some ancient dim
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: prehistoric consciousness, a feeling that they were right somehow--that
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: this was the way to feel. It was like--coming home to mother. I don't
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: mean the underflannels-and-doughnuts mother, the fussy person that waits
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: on you and spoils you and doesn't really know you. I mean the feeling
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: that a very little child would have, who had been lost--for ever so
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: long. It was a sense of getting home; of being clean and rested;
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: of safety and yet freedom; of love that was always there, warm like
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: sunshine in May, not hot like a stove or a featherbed--a love that
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: didn't irritate and didn't smother.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: I looked at Ellador as if I hadn't seen her before. "If you won't go,"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: I said, "I'll get Terry to the coast and come back alone. You can let me
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: down a rope. And if you will go--why you blessed wonder-woman--I would
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: rather live with you all my life--like this--than to have any other
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: woman I ever saw, or any number of them, to do as I like with. Will you
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: come?"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: She was keen for coming. So the plans went on. She'd have liked to wait
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: for that Marvel of Celis's, but Terry had no such desire. He was crazy
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: to be out of it all. It made him sick, he said, SICK; this everlasting
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: mother-mother-mothering. I don't think Terry had what the phrenologists
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: call "the lump of philoprogenitiveness" at all well developed.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Morbid one-sided cripples," he called them, even when from his window
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: he could see their splendid vigor and beauty; even while Moadine, as
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: patient and friendly as if she had never helped Alima to hold and bind
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: him, sat there in the room, the picture of wisdom and serene strength.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Sexless, epicene, undeveloped neuters!" he went on bitterly. He sounded
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: like Sir Almwroth Wright.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Well--it was hard. He was madly in love with Alima, really; more so than
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: he had ever been before, and their tempestuous courtship, quarrels, and
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: reconciliations had fanned the flame. And then when he sought by that
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: supreme conquest which seems so natural a thing to that type of man, to
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: force her to love him as her master--to have the sturdy athletic furious
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: woman rise up and master him--she and her friends--it was no wonder he
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: raged.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Come to think of it, I do not recall a similar case in all history or
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: fiction. Women have killed themselves rather than submit to outrage;
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: they have killed the outrager; they have escaped; or they have
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: submitted--sometimes seeming to get on very well with the victor
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: afterward. There was that adventure of "false Sextus," for instance,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: who "found Lucrese combing the fleece, under the midnight lamp." He
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: threatened, as I remember, that if she did not submit he would slay her,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: slay a slave and place him beside her and say he found him there. A poor
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: device, it always seemed to me. If Mr. Lucretius had asked him how he
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: came to be in his wife's bedroom overlooking her morals, what could he
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: have said? But the point is Lucrese submitted, and Alima didn't.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "She kicked me," confided the embittered prisoner--he had to talk to
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: someone. "I was doubled up with the pain, of course, and she jumped on
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: me and yelled for this old harpy [Moadine couldn't hear him] and they
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: had me trussed up in no time. I believe Alima could have done it alone,"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: he added with reluctant admiration. "She's as strong as a horse. And
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: of course a man's helpless when you hit him like that. No woman with a
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: shade of decency--"
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: I had to grin at that, and even Terry did, sourly. He wasn't given to
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: reasoning, but it did strike him that an assault like his rather waived
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: considerations of decency.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "I'd give a year of my life to have her alone again," he said slowly,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: his hands clenched till the knuckles were white.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: But he never did. She left our end of the country entirely, went up into
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: the fir-forest on the highest slopes, and stayed there. Before we left
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: he quite desperately longed to see her, but she would not come and he
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: could not go. They watched him like lynxes. (Do lynxes watch any better
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: than mousing cats, I wonder!)
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Well--we had to get the flyer in order, and be sure there was enough
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: fuel left, though Terry said we could glide all right, down to that
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: lake, once we got started. We'd have gone gladly in a week's time, of
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: course, but there was a great to-do all over the country about
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Ellador's leaving them. She had interviews with some of the leading
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: ethicists--wise women with still eyes, and with the best of the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: teachers. There was a stir, a thrill, a deep excitement everywhere.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Our teaching about the rest of the world has given them all a sense
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: of isolation, of remoteness, of being a little outlying sample of a
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: country, overlooked and forgotten among the family of nations. We had
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: called it "the family of nations," and they liked the phrase immensely.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: They were deeply aroused on the subject of evolution; indeed, the whole
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: field of natural science drew them irresistibly. Any number of them
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: would have risked everything to go to the strange unknown lands and
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: study; but we could take only one, and it had to be Ellador, naturally.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: We planned greatly about coming back, about establishing a connecting
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: route by water; about penetrating those vast forests and civilizing--or
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: exterminating--the dangerous savages. That is, we men talked of that
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: last--not with the women. They had a definite aversion to killing
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: things.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: But meanwhile there was high council being held among the wisest of them
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: all. The students and thinkers who had been gathering facts from us all
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: this time, collating and relating them, and making inferences, laid the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: result of their labors before the council.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Little had we thought that our careful efforts at concealment had been
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: so easily seen through, with never a word to show us that they saw. They
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: had followed up words of ours on the science of optics, asked innocent
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: questions about glasses and the like, and were aware of the defective
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: eyesight so common among us.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: With the lightest touch, different women asking different questions at
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: different times, and putting all our answers together like a picture
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: puzzle, they had figured out a sort of skeleton chart as to the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: prevalence of disease among us. Even more subtly with no show of horror
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: or condemnation, they had gathered something--far from the truth, but
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: something pretty clear--about poverty, vice, and crime. They even had
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: a goodly number of our dangers all itemized, from asking us about
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: insurance and innocent things like that.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: They were well posted as to the different races, beginning with their
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: poison-arrow natives down below and widening out to the broad racial
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: divisions we had told them about. Never a shocked expression of the face
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: or exclamation of revolt had warned us; they had been extracting the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: evidence without our knowing it all this time, and now were studying
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: with the most devout earnestness the matter they had prepared.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: The result was rather distressing to us. They first explained the matter
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: fully to Ellador, as she was the one who purposed visiting the Rest
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: of the World. To Celis they said nothing. She must not be in any way
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: distressed, while the whole nation waited on her Great Work.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Finally Jeff and I were called in. Somel and Zava were there, and
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Ellador, with many others that we knew.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: They had a great globe, quite fairly mapped out from the small section
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: maps in that compendium of ours. They had the different peoples of the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: earth roughly outlined, and their status in civilization indicated.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: They had charts and figures and estimates, based on the facts in that
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: traitorous little book and what they had learned from us.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Somel explained: "We find that in all your historic period, so much
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: longer than ours, that with all the interplay of services, the exchange
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: of inventions and discoveries, and the wonderful progress we so admire,
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: that in this widespread Other World of yours, there is still much
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: disease, often contagious."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: We admitted this at once.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Also there is still, in varying degree, ignorance, with prejudice and
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: unbridled emotion."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: This too was admitted.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "We find also that in spite of the advance of democracy and the increase
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: of wealth, that there is still unrest and sometimes combat."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Yes, yes, we admitted it all. We were used to these things and saw no
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: reason for so much seriousness.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "All things considered," they said, and they did not say a hundredth
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: part of the things they were considering, "we are unwilling to expose
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: our country to free communication with the rest of the world--as yet. If
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Ellador comes back, and we approve her report, it may be done later--but
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: not yet.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "So we have this to ask of you gentlemen [they knew that word was held
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: a title of honor with us], that you promise not in any way to betray the
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: location of this country until permission--after Ellador's return."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Jeff was perfectly satisfied. He thought they were quite right. He
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: always did. I never saw an alien become naturalized more quickly than
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: that man in Herland.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: I studied it awhile, thinking of the time they'd have if some of our
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: contagions got loose there, and concluded they were right. So I agreed.
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Terry was the obstacle. "Indeed I won't!" he protested. "The first
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: thing I'll do is to get an expedition fixed up to force an entrance into
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: Ma-land."
title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

text: "Then," they said quite calmly, "he must remain an absolute prisoner,
title: Herland

title: Herland
author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins

title: Herland

text: UTOPIA
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: INTRODUCTION
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Sir Thomas More, son of Sir John More, a justice of the King's Bench, was
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: born in 1478, in Milk Street, in the city of London.  After his earlier
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: education at St. Anthony's School, in Threadneedle Street, he was placed,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: as a boy, in the household of Cardinal John Morton, Archbishop of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Canterbury and Lord Chancellor.  It was not unusual for persons of wealth
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: or influence and sons of good families to be so established together in a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: relation of patron and client.  The youth wore his patron's livery, and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: added to his state.  The patron used, afterwards, his wealth or influence
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: in helping his young client forward in the world.  Cardinal Morton had
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: been in earlier days that Bishop of Ely whom Richard III. sent to the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Tower; was busy afterwards in hostility to Richard; and was a chief
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: adviser of Henry VII., who in 1486 made him Archbishop of Canterbury, and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: nine months afterwards Lord Chancellor.  Cardinal Morton--of talk at
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: whose table there are recollections in "Utopia"--delighted in the quick
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: wit of young Thomas More.  He once said, "Whoever shall live to try it,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: shall see this child here waiting at table prove a notable and rare man."
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: At the age of about nineteen, Thomas More was sent to Canterbury College,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Oxford, by his patron, where he learnt Greek of the first men who brought
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Greek studies from Italy to England--William Grocyn and Thomas Linacre.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Linacre, a physician, who afterwards took orders, was also the founder of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the College of Physicians.  In 1499, More left Oxford to study law in
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: London, at Lincoln's Inn, and in the next year Archbishop Morton died.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: More's earnest character caused him while studying law to aim at the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: subduing of the flesh, by wearing a hair shirt, taking a log for a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: pillow, and whipping himself on Fridays.  At the age of twenty-one he
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: entered Parliament, and soon after he had been called to the bar he was
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: made Under-Sheriff of London.  In 1503 he opposed in the House of Commons
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Henry VII.'s proposal for a subsidy on account of the marriage portion of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: his daughter Margaret; and he opposed with so much energy that the House
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: refused to grant it.  One went and told the king that a beardless boy had
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: disappointed all his expectations.  During the last years, therefore, of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Henry VII.  More was under the displeasure of the king, and had thoughts
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of leaving the country.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Henry VII. died in April, 1509, when More's age was a little over thirty.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: In the first years of the reign of Henry VIII. he rose to large practice
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: in the law courts, where it is said he refused to plead in cases which he
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: thought unjust, and took no fees from widows, orphans, or the poor.  He
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: would have preferred marrying the second daughter of John Colt, of New
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Hall, in Essex, but chose her elder sister, that he might not subject her
title: Utopia

text: contrived as near in the same manner as the ground on which they stand
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: will allow.  The nearest lie at least twenty-four miles' distance from
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: one another, and the most remote are not so far distant but that a man
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: can go on foot in one day from it to that which lies next it.  Every city
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: sends three of their wisest senators once a year to Amaurot, to consult
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: about their common concerns; for that is the chief town of the island,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: being situated near the centre of it, so that it is the most convenient
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: place for their assemblies.  The jurisdiction of every city extends at
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: least twenty miles, and, where the towns lie wider, they have much more
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: ground.  No town desires to enlarge its bounds, for the people consider
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: themselves rather as tenants than landlords.  They have built, over all
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the country, farmhouses for husbandmen, which are well contrived, and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: furnished with all things necessary for country labour.  Inhabitants are
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: sent, by turns, from the cities to dwell in them; no country family has
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: fewer than forty men and women in it, besides two slaves.  There is a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: master and a mistress set over every family, and over thirty families
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: there is a magistrate.  Every year twenty of this family come back to the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: town after they have stayed two years in the country, and in their room
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: there are other twenty sent from the town, that they may learn country
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: work from those that have been already one year in the country, as they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: must teach those that come to them the next from the town.  By this means
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: such as dwell in those country farms are never ignorant of agriculture,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and so commit no errors which might otherwise be fatal and bring them
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: under a scarcity of corn.  But though there is every year such a shifting
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of the husbandmen to prevent any man being forced against his will to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: follow that hard course of life too long, yet many among them take such
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: pleasure in it that they desire leave to continue in it many years.  These
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: husbandmen till the ground, breed cattle, hew wood, and convey it to the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: towns either by land or water, as is most convenient.  They breed an
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: infinite multitude of chickens in a very curious manner; for the hens do
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: not sit and hatch them, but a vast number of eggs are laid in a gentle
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and equal heat in order to be hatched, and they are no sooner out of the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: shell, and able to stir about, but they seem to consider those that feed
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: them as their mothers, and follow them as other chickens do the hen that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: hatched them.  They breed very few horses, but those they have are full
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of mettle, and are kept only for exercising their youth in the art of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: sitting and riding them; for they do not put them to any work, either of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: ploughing or carriage, in which they employ oxen.  For though their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: horses are stronger, yet they find oxen can hold out longer; and as they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: are not subject to so many diseases, so they are kept upon a less charge
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and with less trouble.  And even when they are so worn out that they are
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: no more fit for labour, they are good meat at last.  They sow no corn but
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: that which is to be their bread; for they drink either wine, cider or
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: perry, and often water, sometimes boiled with honey or liquorice, with
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: which they abound; and though they know exactly how much corn will serve
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: every town and all that tract of country which belongs to it, yet they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: sow much more and breed more cattle than are necessary for their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: consumption, and they give that overplus of which they make no use to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: their neighbours.  When they want anything in the country which it does
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: not produce, they fetch that from the town, without carrying anything in
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: exchange for it.  And the magistrates of the town take care to see it
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: given them; for they meet generally in the town once a month, upon a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: festival day.  When the time of harvest comes, the magistrates in the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: country send to those in the towns and let them know how many hands they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: will need for reaping the harvest; and the number they call for being
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: sent to them, they commonly despatch it all in one day.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: OF THEIR TOWNS, PARTICULARLY OF AMAUROT
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "He that knows one of their towns knows them all--they are so like one
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: another, except where the situation makes some difference.  I shall
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: therefore describe one of them, and none is so proper as Amaurot; for as
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: none is more eminent (all the rest yielding in precedence to this,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: because it is the seat of their supreme council), so there was none of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: them better known to me, I having lived five years all together in it.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "It lies upon the side of a hill, or, rather, a rising ground.  Its
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: figure is almost square, for from the one side of it, which shoots up
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: almost to the top of the hill, it runs down, in a descent for two miles,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: to the river Anider; but it is a little broader the other way that runs
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: along by the bank of that river.  The Anider rises about eighty miles
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: above Amaurot, in a small spring at first.  But other brooks falling into
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: it, of which two are more considerable than the rest, as it runs by
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Amaurot it is grown half a mile broad; but, it still grows larger and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: larger, till, after sixty miles' course below it, it is lost in the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: ocean.  Between the town and the sea, and for some miles above the town,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: it ebbs and flows every six hours with a strong current.  The tide comes
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: up about thirty miles so full that there is nothing but salt water in the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: river, the fresh water being driven back with its force; and above that,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: for some miles, the water is brackish; but a little higher, as it runs by
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the town, it is quite fresh; and when the tide ebbs, it continues fresh
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: all along to the sea.  There is a bridge cast over the river, not of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: timber, but of fair stone, consisting of many stately arches; it lies at
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: that part of the town which is farthest from the sea, so that the ships,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: without any hindrance, lie all along the side of the town.  There is,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: likewise, another river that runs by it, which, though it is not great,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: yet it runs pleasantly, for it rises out of the same hill on which the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: town stands, and so runs down through it and falls into the Anider.  The
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: inhabitants have fortified the fountain-head of this river, which springs
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: a little without the towns; that so, if they should happen to be
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: besieged, the enemy might not be able to stop or divert the course of the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: water, nor poison it; from thence it is carried, in earthen pipes, to the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: lower streets.  And for those places of the town to which the water of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: that small river cannot be conveyed, they have great cisterns for
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: receiving the rain-water, which supplies the want of the other.  The town
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: is compassed with a high and thick wall, in which there are many towers
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and forts; there is also a broad and deep dry ditch, set thick with
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: thorns, cast round three sides of the town, and the river is instead of a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: ditch on the fourth side.  The streets are very convenient for all
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: carriage, and are well sheltered from the winds.  Their buildings are
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: good, and are so uniform that a whole side of a street looks like one
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: house.  The streets are twenty feet broad; there lie gardens behind all
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: their houses.  These are large, but enclosed with buildings, that on all
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: hands face the streets, so that every house has both a door to the street
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and a back door to the garden.  Their doors have all two leaves, which,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: as they are easily opened, so they shut of their own accord; and, there
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: being no property among them, every man may freely enter into any house
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: whatsoever.  At every ten years' end they shift their houses by lots.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: They cultivate their gardens with great care, so that they have both
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: vines, fruits, herbs, and flowers in them; and all is so well ordered and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: so finely kept that I never saw gardens anywhere that were both so
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: fruitful and so beautiful as theirs.  And this humour of ordering their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: gardens so well is not only kept up by the pleasure they find in it, but
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: also by an emulation between the inhabitants of the several streets, who
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: vie with each other.  And there is, indeed, nothing belonging to the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: whole town that is both more useful and more pleasant.  So that he who
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: founded the town seems to have taken care of nothing more than of their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: gardens; for they say the whole scheme of the town was designed at first
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: by Utopus, but he left all that belonged to the ornament and improvement
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of it to be added by those that should come after him, that being too
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: much for one man to bring to perfection.  Their records, that contain the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: history of their town and State, are preserved with an exact care, and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: run backwards seventeen hundred and sixty years.  From these it appears
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: that their houses were at first low and mean, like cottages, made of any
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: sort of timber, and were built with mud walls and thatched with straw.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: But now their houses are three storeys high, the fronts of them are faced
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: either with stone, plastering, or brick, and between the facings of their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: walls they throw in their rubbish.  Their roofs are flat, and on them
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: they lay a sort of plaster, which costs very little, and yet is so
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: tempered that it is not apt to take fire, and yet resists the weather
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: more than lead.  They have great quantities of glass among them, with
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: which they glaze their windows; they use also in their windows a thin
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: linen cloth, that is so oiled or gummed that it both keeps out the wind
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and gives free admission to the light.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: OF THEIR MAGISTRATES
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "Thirty families choose every year a magistrate, who was anciently called
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the Syphogrant, but is now called the Philarch; and over every ten
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Syphogrants, with the families subject to them, there is another
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: magistrate, who was anciently called the Tranibore, but of late the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Archphilarch.  All the Syphogrants, who are in number two hundred, choose
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the Prince out of a list of four who are named by the people of the four
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: divisions of the city; but they take an oath, before they proceed to an
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: election, that they will choose him whom they think most fit for the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: office: they give him their voices secretly, so that it is not known for
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: whom every one gives his suffrage.  The Prince is for life, unless he is
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: removed upon suspicion of some design to enslave the people.  The
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Tranibors are new chosen every year, but yet they are, for the most part,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: continued; all their other magistrates are only annual.  The Tranibors
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: meet every third day, and oftener if necessary, and consult with the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Prince either concerning the affairs of the State in general, or such
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: private differences as may arise sometimes among the people, though that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: falls out but seldom.  There are always two Syphogrants called into the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: council chamber, and these are changed every day.  It is a fundamental
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: rule of their government, that no conclusion can be made in anything that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: relates to the public till it has been first debated three several days
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: in their council.  It is death for any to meet and consult concerning the
title: Utopia
