author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: State, unless it be either in their ordinary council, or in the assembly
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of the whole body of the people.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "These things have been so provided among them that the Prince and the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Tranibors may not conspire together to change the government and enslave
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the people; and therefore when anything of great importance is set on
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: foot, it is sent to the Syphogrants, who, after they have communicated it
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: to the families that belong to their divisions, and have considered it
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: among themselves, make report to the senate; and, upon great occasions,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the matter is referred to the council of the whole island.  One rule
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: observed in their council is, never to debate a thing on the same day in
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: which it is first proposed; for that is always referred to the next
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: meeting, that so men may not rashly and in the heat of discourse engage
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: themselves too soon, which might bias them so much that, instead of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: consulting the good of the public, they might rather study to support
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: their first opinions, and by a perverse and preposterous sort of shame
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: hazard their country rather than endanger their own reputation, or
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: venture the being suspected to have wanted foresight in the expedients
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: that they at first proposed; and therefore, to prevent this, they take
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: care that they may rather be deliberate than sudden in their motions.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: OF THEIR TRADES, AND MANNER OF LIFE
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "Agriculture is that which is so universally understood among them that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: no person, either man or woman, is ignorant of it; they are instructed in
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: it from their childhood, partly by what they learn at school, and partly
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: by practice, they being led out often into the fields about the town,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: where they not only see others at work but are likewise exercised in it
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: themselves.  Besides agriculture, which is so common to them all, every
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: man has some peculiar trade to which he applies himself; such as the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: manufacture of wool or flax, masonry, smith's work, or carpenter's work;
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: for there is no sort of trade that is in great esteem among them.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Throughout the island they wear the same sort of clothes, without any
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: other distinction except what is necessary to distinguish the two sexes
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and the married and unmarried.  The fashion never alters, and as it is
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: neither disagreeable nor uneasy, so it is suited to the climate, and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: calculated both for their summers and winters.  Every family makes their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: own clothes; but all among them, women as well as men, learn one or other
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of the trades formerly mentioned.  Women, for the most part, deal in wool
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and flax, which suit best with their weakness, leaving the ruder trades
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: to the men.  The same trade generally passes down from father to son,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: inclinations often following descent: but if any man's genius lies
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: another way he is, by adoption, translated into a family that deals in
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the trade to which he is inclined; and when that is to be done, care is
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: taken, not only by his father, but by the magistrate, that he may be put
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: to a discreet and good man: and if, after a person has learned one trade,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: he desires to acquire another, that is also allowed, and is managed in
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the same manner as the former.  When he has learned both, he follows that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: which he likes best, unless the public has more occasion for the other.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: The chief, and almost the only, business of the Syphogrants is to take
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: care that no man may live idle, but that every one may follow his trade
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: diligently; yet they do not wear themselves out with perpetual toil from
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: morning to night, as if they were beasts of burden, which as it is indeed
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: a heavy slavery, so it is everywhere the common course of life amongst
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: all mechanics except the Utopians: but they, dividing the day and night
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: into twenty-four hours, appoint six of these for work, three of which are
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: before dinner and three after; they then sup, and at eight o'clock,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: counting from noon, go to bed and sleep eight hours: the rest of their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: time, besides that taken up in work, eating, and sleeping, is left to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: every man's discretion; yet they are not to abuse that interval to luxury
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and idleness, but must employ it in some proper exercise, according to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: their various inclinations, which is, for the most part, reading.  It is
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: ordinary to have public lectures every morning before daybreak, at which
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: none are obliged to appear but those who are marked out for literature;
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: yet a great many, both men and women, of all ranks, go to hear lectures
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of one sort or other, according to their inclinations: but if others that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: are not made for contemplation, choose rather to employ themselves at
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: that time in their trades, as many of them do, they are not hindered, but
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: are rather commended, as men that take care to serve their country.  After
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: supper they spend an hour in some diversion, in summer in their gardens,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and in winter in the halls where they eat, where they entertain each
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: other either with music or discourse.  They do not so much as know dice,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: or any such foolish and mischievous games.  They have, however, two sorts
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of games not unlike our chess; the one is between several numbers, in
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: which one number, as it were, consumes another; the other resembles a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: battle between the virtues and the vices, in which the enmity in the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: vices among themselves, and their agreement against virtue, is not
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: unpleasantly represented; together with the special opposition between
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the particular virtues and vices; as also the methods by which vice
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: either openly assaults or secretly undermines virtue; and virtue, on the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: other hand, resists it.  But the time appointed for labour is to be
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: narrowly examined, otherwise you may imagine that since there are only
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: six hours appointed for work, they may fall under a scarcity of necessary
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: provisions: but it is so far from being true that this time is not
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: sufficient for supplying them with plenty of all things, either necessary
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: or convenient, that it is rather too much; and this you will easily
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: apprehend if you consider how great a part of all other nations is quite
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: idle.  First, women generally do little, who are the half of mankind; and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: if some few women are diligent, their husbands are idle: then consider
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the great company of idle priests, and of those that are called religious
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: men; add to these all rich men, chiefly those that have estates in land,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: who are called noblemen and gentlemen, together with their families, made
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: up of idle persons, that are kept more for show than use; add to these
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: all those strong and lusty beggars that go about pretending some disease
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: in excuse for their begging; and upon the whole account you will find
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: that the number of those by whose labours mankind is supplied is much
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: less than you perhaps imagined: then consider how few of those that work
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: are employed in labours that are of real service, for we, who measure all
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: things by money, give rise to many trades that are both vain and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: superfluous, and serve only to support riot and luxury: for if those who
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: work were employed only in such things as the conveniences of life
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: require, there would be such an abundance of them that the prices of them
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: would so sink that tradesmen could not be maintained by their gains; if
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: all those who labour about useless things were set to more profitable
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: employments, and if all they that languish out their lives in sloth and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: idleness (every one of whom consumes as much as any two of the men that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: are at work) were forced to labour, you may easily imagine that a small
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: proportion of time would serve for doing all that is either necessary,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: profitable, or pleasant to mankind, especially while pleasure is kept
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: within its due bounds: this appears very plainly in Utopia; for there, in
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: a great city, and in all the territory that lies round it, you can scarce
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: find five hundred, either men or women, by their age and strength capable
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of labour, that are not engaged in it.  Even the Syphogrants, though
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: excused by the law, yet do not excuse themselves, but work, that by their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: examples they may excite the industry of the rest of the people; the like
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: exemption is allowed to those who, being recommended to the people by the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: priests, are, by the secret suffrages of the Syphogrants, privileged from
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: labour, that they may apply themselves wholly to study; and if any of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: these fall short of those hopes that they seemed at first to give, they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: are obliged to return to work; and sometimes a mechanic that so employs
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: his leisure hours as to make a considerable advancement in learning is
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: eased from being a tradesman and ranked among their learned men.  Out of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: these they choose their ambassadors, their priests, their Tranibors, and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the Prince himself, anciently called their Barzenes, but is called of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: late their Ademus.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "And thus from the great numbers among them that are neither suffered to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: be idle nor to be employed in any fruitless labour, you may easily make
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the estimate how much may be done in those few hours in which they are
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: obliged to labour.  But, besides all that has been already said, it is to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: be considered that the needful arts among them are managed with less
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: labour than anywhere else.  The building or the repairing of houses among
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: us employ many hands, because often a thriftless heir suffers a house
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: that his father built to fall into decay, so that his successor must, at
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: a great cost, repair that which he might have kept up with a small
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: charge; it frequently happens that the same house which one person built
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: at a vast expense is neglected by another, who thinks he has a more
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: delicate sense of the beauties of architecture, and he, suffering it to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: fall to ruin, builds another at no less charge.  But among the Utopians
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: all things are so regulated that men very seldom build upon a new piece
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of ground, and are not only very quick in repairing their houses, but
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: show their foresight in preventing their decay, so that their buildings
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: are preserved very long with but very little labour, and thus the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: builders, to whom that care belongs, are often without employment, except
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the hewing of timber and the squaring of stones, that the materials may
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: be in readiness for raising a building very suddenly when there is any
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: occasion for it.  As to their clothes, observe how little work is spent
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: in them; while they are at labour they are clothed with leather and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: skins, cut carelessly about them, which will last seven years, and when
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: they appear in public they put on an upper garment which hides the other;
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and these are all of one colour, and that is the natural colour of the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: wool.  As they need less woollen cloth than is used anywhere else, so
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: that which they make use of is much less costly; they use linen cloth
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: more, but that is prepared with less labour, and they value cloth only by
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the whiteness of the linen or the cleanness of the wool, without much
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: regard to the fineness of the thread.  While in other places four or five
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: upper garments of woollen cloth of different colours, and as many vests
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of silk, will scarce serve one man, and while those that are nicer think
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: ten too few, every man there is content with one, which very often serves
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: him two years; nor is there anything that can tempt a man to desire more,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: for if he had them he would neither be the, warmer nor would he make one
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: jot the better appearance for it.  And thus, since they are all employed
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: in some useful labour, and since they content themselves with fewer
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: things, it falls out that there is a great abundance of all things among
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: them; so that it frequently happens that, for want of other work, vast
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: numbers are sent out to mend the highways; but when no public undertaking
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: is to be performed, the hours of working are lessened.  The magistrates
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: never engage the people in unnecessary labour, since the chief end of the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: constitution is to regulate labour by the necessities of the public, and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: to allow the people as much time as is necessary for the improvement of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: their minds, in which they think the happiness of life consists.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: OF THEIR TRAFFIC
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "But it is now time to explain to you the mutual intercourse of this
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: people, their commerce, and the rules by which all things are distributed
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: among them.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "As their cities are composed of families, so their families are made up
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of those that are nearly related to one another.  Their women, when they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: grow up, are married out, but all the males, both children and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: grand-children, live still in the same house, in great obedience to their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: common parent, unless age has weakened his understanding, and in that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: case he that is next to him in age comes in his room; but lest any city
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: should become either too great, or by any accident be dispeopled,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: provision is made that none of their cities may contain above six
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: thousand families, besides those of the country around it.  No family may
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: have less than ten and more than sixteen persons in it, but there can be
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: no determined number for the children under age; this rule is easily
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: observed by removing some of the children of a more fruitful couple to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: any other family that does not abound so much in them.  By the same rule
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: they supply cities that do not increase so fast from others that breed
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: faster; and if there is any increase over the whole island, then they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: draw out a number of their citizens out of the several towns and send
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: them over to the neighbouring continent, where, if they find that the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: inhabitants have more soil than they can well cultivate, they fix a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: colony, taking the inhabitants into their society if they are willing to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: live with them; and where they do that of their own accord, they quickly
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: enter into their method of life and conform to their rules, and this
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: proves a happiness to both nations; for, according to their constitution,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: such care is taken of the soil that it becomes fruitful enough for both,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: though it might be otherwise too narrow and barren for any one of them.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: But if the natives refuse to conform themselves to their laws they drive
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: them out of those bounds which they mark out for themselves, and use
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: force if they resist, for they account it a very just cause of war for a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: nation to hinder others from possessing a part of that soil of which they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: make no use, but which is suffered to lie idle and uncultivated, since
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: every man has, by the law of nature, a right to such a waste portion of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the earth as is necessary for his subsistence.  If an accident has so
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: lessened the number of the inhabitants of any of their towns that it
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: cannot be made up from the other towns of the island without diminishing
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: them too much (which is said to have fallen out but twice since they were
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: first a people, when great numbers were carried off by the plague), the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: loss is then supplied by recalling as many as are wanted from their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: colonies, for they will abandon these rather than suffer the towns in the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: island to sink too low.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "But to return to their manner of living in society: the oldest man of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: every family, as has been already said, is its governor; wives serve
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: their husbands, and children their parents, and always the younger serves
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the elder.  Every city is divided into four equal parts, and in the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: middle of each there is a market-place.  What is brought thither, and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: manufactured by the several families, is carried from thence to houses
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: appointed for that purpose, in which all things of a sort are laid by
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: themselves; and thither every father goes, and takes whatsoever he or his
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: family stand in need of, without either paying for it or leaving anything
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: in exchange.  There is no reason for giving a denial to any person, since
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: there is such plenty of everything among them; and there is no danger of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: a man's asking for more than he needs; they have no inducements to do
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: this, since they are sure they shall always be supplied: it is the fear
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of want that makes any of the whole race of animals either greedy or
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: ravenous; but, besides fear, there is in man a pride that makes him fancy
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: it a particular glory to excel others in pomp and excess; but by the laws
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of the Utopians, there is no room for this.  Near these markets there are
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: others for all sorts of provisions, where there are not only herbs,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: fruits, and bread, but also fish, fowl, and cattle.  There are also,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: without their towns, places appointed near some running water for killing
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: their beasts and for washing away their filth, which is done by their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: slaves; for they suffer none of their citizens to kill their cattle,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: because they think that pity and good-nature, which are among the best of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: those affections that are born with us, are much impaired by the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: butchering of animals; nor do they suffer anything that is foul or
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: unclean to be brought within their towns, lest the air should be infected
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: by ill-smells, which might prejudice their health.  In every street there
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: are great halls, that lie at an equal distance from each other,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: distinguished by particular names.  The Syphogrants dwell in those that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: are set over thirty families, fifteen lying on one side of it, and as
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: many on the other.  In these halls they all meet and have their repasts;
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the stewards of every one of them come to the market-place at an
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: appointed hour, and according to the number of those that belong to the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: hall they carry home provisions.  But they take more care of their sick
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: than of any others; these are lodged and provided for in public
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: hospitals.  They have belonging to every town four hospitals, that are
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: built without their walls, and are so large that they may pass for little
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: towns; by this means, if they had ever such a number of sick persons,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: they could lodge them conveniently, and at such a distance that such of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: them as are sick of infectious diseases may be kept so far from the rest
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: that there can be no danger of contagion.  The hospitals are furnished
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and stored with all things that are convenient for the ease and recovery
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of the sick; and those that are put in them are looked after with such
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: tender and watchful care, and are so constantly attended by their skilful
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: physicians, that as none is sent to them against their will, so there is
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: scarce one in a whole town that, if he should fall ill, would not choose
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: rather to go thither than lie sick at home.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "After the steward of the hospitals has taken for the sick whatsoever the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: physician prescribes, then the best things that are left in the market
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: are distributed equally among the halls in proportion to their numbers;
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: only, in the first place, they serve the Prince, the Chief Priest, the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Tranibors, the Ambassadors, and strangers, if there are any, which,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: indeed, falls out but seldom, and for whom there are houses, well
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: furnished, particularly appointed for their reception when they come
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: among them.  At the hours of dinner and supper the whole Syphogranty
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: being called together by sound of trumpet, they meet and eat together,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: except only such as are in the hospitals or lie sick at home.  Yet, after
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the halls are served, no man is hindered to carry provisions home from
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the market-place, for they know that none does that but for some good
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: reason; for though any that will may eat at home, yet none does it
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: willingly, since it is both ridiculous and foolish for any to give
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: themselves the trouble to make ready an ill dinner at home when there is
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: a much more plentiful one made ready for him so near hand.  All the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: uneasy and sordid services about these halls are performed by their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: slaves; but the dressing and cooking their meat, and the ordering their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: tables, belong only to the women, all those of every family taking it by
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: turns.  They sit at three or more tables, according to their number; the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: men sit towards the wall, and the women sit on the other side, that if
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: any of them should be taken suddenly ill, which is no uncommon case
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: amongst women with child, she may, without disturbing the rest, rise and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: go to the nurses' room (who are there with the sucking children), where
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: there is always clean water at hand and cradles, in which they may lay
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the young children if there is occasion for it, and a fire, that they may
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: shift and dress them before it.  Every child is nursed by its own mother
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: if death or sickness does not intervene; and in that case the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Syphogrants' wives find out a nurse quickly, which is no hard matter, for
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: any one that can do it offers herself cheerfully; for as they are much
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: inclined to that piece of mercy, so the child whom they nurse considers
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the nurse as its mother.  All the children under five years old sit among
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the nurses; the rest of the younger sort of both sexes, till they are fit
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: for marriage, either serve those that sit at table, or, if they are not
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: strong enough for that, stand by them in great silence and eat what is
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: given them; nor have they any other formality of dining.  In the middle
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of the first table, which stands across the upper end of the hall, sit
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the Syphogrant and his wife, for that is the chief and most conspicuous
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: place; next to him sit two of the most ancient, for there go always four
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: to a mess.  If there is a temple within the Syphogranty, the Priest and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: his wife sit with the Syphogrant above all the rest; next them there is a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: mixture of old and young, who are so placed that as the young are set
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: near others, so they are mixed with the more ancient; which, they say,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: was appointed on this account: that the gravity of the old people, and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the reverence that is due to them, might restrain the younger from all
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: indecent words and gestures.  Dishes are not served up to the whole table
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: at first, but the best are first set before the old, whose seats are
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: distinguished from the young, and, after them, all the rest are served
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: alike.  The old men distribute to the younger any curious meats that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: happen to be set before them, if there is not such an abundance of them
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: that the whole company may be served alike.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "Thus old men are honoured with a particular respect, yet all the rest
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: fare as well as they.  Both dinner and supper are begun with some lecture
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of morality that is read to them; but it is so short that it is not
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: tedious nor uneasy to them to hear it.  From hence the old men take
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: occasion to entertain those about them with some useful and pleasant
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: enlargements; but they do not engross the whole discourse so to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: themselves during their meals that the younger may not put in for a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: share; on the contrary, they engage them to talk, that so they may, in
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: that free way of conversation, find out the force of every one's spirit
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and observe his temper.  They despatch their dinners quickly, but sit
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: long at supper, because they go to work after the one, and are to sleep
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: after the other, during which they think the stomach carries on the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: concoction more vigorously.  They never sup without music, and there is
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: always fruit served up after meat; while they are at table some burn
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: perfumes and sprinkle about fragrant ointments and sweet waters--in
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: short, they want nothing that may cheer up their spirits; they give
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: themselves a large allowance that way, and indulge themselves in all such
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: pleasures as are attended with no inconvenience.  Thus do those that are
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: in the towns live together; but in the country, where they live at a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: great distance, every one eats at home, and no family wants any necessary
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: sort of provision, for it is from them that provisions are sent unto
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: those that live in the towns.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: OF THE TRAVELLING OF THE UTOPIANS
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: If any man has a mind to visit his friends that live in some other town,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: or desires to travel and see the rest of the country, he obtains leave
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: very easily from the Syphogrant and Tranibors, when there is no
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: particular occasion for him at home.  Such as travel carry with them a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: passport from the Prince, which both certifies the licence that is
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: granted for travelling, and limits the time of their return.  They are
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: furnished with a waggon and a slave, who drives the oxen and looks after
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: them; but, unless there are women in the company, the waggon is sent back
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: at the end of the journey as a needless encumbrance.  While they are on
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the road they carry no provisions with them, yet they want for nothing,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: but are everywhere treated as if they were at home.  If they stay in any
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: place longer than a night, every one follows his proper occupation, and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: is very well used by those of his own trade; but if any man goes out of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the city to which he belongs without leave, and is found rambling without
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: a passport, he is severely treated, he is punished as a fugitive, and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: sent home disgracefully; and, if he falls again into the like fault, is
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: condemned to slavery.  If any man has a mind to travel only over the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: precinct of his own city, he may freely do it, with his father's
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: permission and his wife's consent; but when he comes into any of the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: country houses, if he expects to be entertained by them, he must labour
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: with them and conform to their rules; and if he does this, he may freely
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: go over the whole precinct, being then as useful to the city to which he
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: belongs as if he were still within it.  Thus you see that there are no
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: idle persons among them, nor pretences of excusing any from labour.  There
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: are no taverns, no ale-houses, nor stews among them, nor any other
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: occasions of corrupting each other, of getting into corners, or forming
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: themselves into parties; all men live in full view, so that all are
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: obliged both to perform their ordinary task and to employ themselves well
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: in their spare hours; and it is certain that a people thus ordered must
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: live in great abundance of all things, and these being equally
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: distributed among them, no man can want or be obliged to beg.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "In their great council at Amaurot, to which there are three sent from
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: every town once a year, they examine what towns abound in provisions and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: what are under any scarcity, that so the one may be furnished from the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: other; and this is done freely, without any sort of exchange; for,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: according to their plenty or scarcity, they supply or are supplied from
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: one another, so that indeed the whole island is, as it were, one family.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: When they have thus taken care of their whole country, and laid up stores
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: for two years (which they do to prevent the ill consequences of an
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: unfavourable season), they order an exportation of the overplus, both of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: corn, honey, wool, flax, wood, wax, tallow, leather, and cattle, which
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: they send out, commonly in great quantities, to other nations.  They
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: order a seventh part of all these goods to be freely given to the poor of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the countries to which they send them, and sell the rest at moderate
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: rates; and by this exchange they not only bring back those few things
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: that they need at home (for, indeed, they scarce need anything but iron),
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: but likewise a great deal of gold and silver; and by their driving this
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: trade so long, it is not to be imagined how vast a treasure they have got
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: among them, so that now they do not much care whether they sell off their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: merchandise for money in hand or upon trust.  A great part of their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: treasure is now in bonds; but in all their contracts no private man
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: stands bound, but the writing runs in the name of the town; and the towns
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: that owe them money raise it from those private hands that owe it to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: them, lay it up in their public chamber, or enjoy the profit of it till
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the Utopians call for it; and they choose rather to let the greatest part
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of it lie in their hands, who make advantage by it, than to call for it
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: themselves; but if they see that any of their other neighbours stand more
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: in need of it, then they call it in and lend it to them.  Whenever they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: are engaged in war, which is the only occasion in which their treasure
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: can be usefully employed, they make use of it themselves; in great
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: extremities or sudden accidents they employ it in hiring foreign troops,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: whom they more willingly expose to danger than their own people; they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: give them great pay, knowing well that this will work even on their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: enemies; that it will engage them either to betray their own side, or, at
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: least, to desert it; and that it is the best means of raising mutual
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: jealousies among them.  For this end they have an incredible treasure;
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: but they do not keep it as a treasure, but in such a manner as I am
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: almost afraid to tell, lest you think it so extravagant as to be hardly
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: credible.  This I have the more reason to apprehend because, if I had not
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: seen it myself, I could not have been easily persuaded to have believed
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: it upon any man's report.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "It is certain that all things appear incredible to us in proportion as
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: they differ from known customs; but one who can judge aright will not
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: wonder to find that, since their constitution differs so much from ours,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: their value of gold and silver should be measured by a very different
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: standard; for since they have no use for money among themselves, but keep
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: it as a provision against events which seldom happen, and between which
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: there are generally long intervening intervals, they value it no farther
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: than it deserves--that is, in proportion to its use.  So that it is plain
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: they must prefer iron either to gold or silver, for men can no more live
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: without iron than without fire or water; but Nature has marked out no use
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: for the other metals so essential as not easily to be dispensed with.  The
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: folly of men has enhanced the value of gold and silver because of their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: scarcity; whereas, on the contrary, it is their opinion that Nature, as
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: an indulgent parent, has freely given us all the best things in great
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: abundance, such as water and earth, but has laid up and hid from us the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: things that are vain and useless.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "If these metals were laid up in any tower in the kingdom it would raise
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: a jealousy of the Prince and Senate, and give birth to that foolish
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: mistrust into which the people are apt to fall--a jealousy of their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: intending to sacrifice the interest of the public to their own private
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: advantage.  If they should work it into vessels, or any sort of plate,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: they fear that the people might grow too fond of it, and so be unwilling
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: to let the plate be run down, if a war made it necessary, to employ it in
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: paying their soldiers.  To prevent all these inconveniences they have
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: fallen upon an expedient which, as it agrees with their other policy, so
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: is it very different from ours, and will scarce gain belief among us who
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: value gold so much, and lay it up so carefully.  They eat and drink out
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of vessels of earth or glass, which make an agreeable appearance, though
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: formed of brittle materials; while they make their chamber-pots and close-
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: stools of gold and silver, and that not only in their public halls but in
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: their private houses.  Of the same metals they likewise make chains and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: fetters for their slaves, to some of which, as a badge of infamy, they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: hang an earring of gold, and make others wear a chain or a coronet of the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: same metal; and thus they take care by all possible means to render gold
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and silver of no esteem; and from hence it is that while other nations
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: part with their gold and silver as unwillingly as if one tore out their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: bowels, those of Utopia would look on their giving in all they possess of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: those metals (when there were any use for them) but as the parting with a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: trifle, or as we would esteem the loss of a penny!  They find pearls on
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: their coasts, and diamonds and carbuncles on their rocks; they do not
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: look after them, but, if they find them by chance, they polish them, and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: with them they adorn their children, who are delighted with them, and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: glory in them during their childhood; but when they grow to years, and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: see that none but children use such baubles, they of their own accord,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: without being bid by their parents, lay them aside, and would be as much
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: ashamed to use them afterwards as children among us, when they come to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: years, are of their puppets and other toys.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "I never saw a clearer instance of the opposite impressions that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: different customs make on people than I observed in the ambassadors of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the Anemolians, who came to Amaurot when I was there.  As they came to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: treat of affairs of great consequence, the deputies from several towns
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: met together to wait for their coming.  The ambassadors of the nations
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: that lie near Utopia, knowing their customs, and that fine clothes are in
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: no esteem among them, that silk is despised, and gold is a badge of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: infamy, used to come very modestly clothed; but the Anemolians, lying
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: more remote, and having had little commerce with them, understanding that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: they were coarsely clothed, and all in the same manner, took it for
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: granted that they had none of those fine things among them of which they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: made no use; and they, being a vainglorious rather than a wise people,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: resolved to set themselves out with so much pomp that they should look
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: like gods, and strike the eyes of the poor Utopians with their splendour.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Thus three ambassadors made their entry with a hundred attendants, all
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: clad in garments of different colours, and the greater part in silk; the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: ambassadors themselves, who were of the nobility of their country, were
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: in cloth-of-gold, and adorned with massy chains, earrings and rings of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: gold; their caps were covered with bracelets set full of pearls and other
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: gems--in a word, they were set out with all those things that among the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Utopians were either the badges of slavery, the marks of infamy, or the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: playthings of children.  It was not unpleasant to see, on the one side,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: how they looked big, when they compared their rich habits with the plain
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: clothes of the Utopians, who were come out in great numbers to see them
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: make their entry; and, on the other, to observe how much they were
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: mistaken in the impression which they hoped this pomp would have made on
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: them.  It appeared so ridiculous a show to all that had never stirred out
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of their country, and had not seen the customs of other nations, that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: though they paid some reverence to those that were the most meanly clad,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: as if they had been the ambassadors, yet when they saw the ambassadors
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: themselves so full of gold and chains, they looked upon them as slaves,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and forbore to treat them with reverence.  You might have seen the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: children who were grown big enough to despise their playthings, and who
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: had thrown away their jewels, call to their mothers, push them gently,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and cry out, 'See that great fool, that wears pearls and gems as if he
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: were yet a child!' while their mothers very innocently replied, 'Hold
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: your peace! this, I believe, is one of the ambassadors' fools.'  Others
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: censured the fashion of their chains, and observed, 'That they were of no
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: use, for they were too slight to bind their slaves, who could easily
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: break them; and, besides, hung so loose about them that they thought it
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: easy to throw their away, and so get from them."  But after the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: ambassadors had stayed a day among them, and saw so vast a quantity of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: gold in their houses (which was as much despised by them as it was
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: esteemed in other nations), and beheld more gold and silver in the chains
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and fetters of one slave than all their ornaments amounted to, their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: plumes fell, and they were ashamed of all that glory for which they had
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: formed valued themselves, and accordingly laid it aside--a resolution
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: that they immediately took when, on their engaging in some free discourse
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: with the Utopians, they discovered their sense of such things and their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: other customs.  The Utopians wonder how any man should be so much taken
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: with the glaring doubtful lustre of a jewel or a stone, that can look up
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: to a star or to the sun himself; or how any should value himself because
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: his cloth is made of a finer thread; for, how fine soever that thread may
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: be, it was once no better than the fleece of a sheep, and that sheep, was
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: a sheep still, for all its wearing it.  They wonder much to hear that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: gold, which in itself is so useless a thing, should be everywhere so much
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: esteemed that even man, for whom it was made, and by whom it has its
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: value, should yet be thought of less value than this metal; that a man of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: lead, who has no more sense than a log of wood, and is as bad as he is
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: foolish, should have many wise and good men to serve him, only because he
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: has a great heap of that metal; and that if it should happen that by some
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: accident or trick of law (which, sometimes produces as great changes as
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: chance itself) all this wealth should pass from the master to the meanest
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: varlet of his whole family, he himself would very soon become one of his
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: servants, as if he were a thing that belonged to his wealth, and so were
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: bound to follow its fortune!  But they much more admire and detest the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: folly of those who, when they see a rich man, though they neither owe him
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: anything, nor are in any sort dependent on his bounty, yet, merely
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: because he is rich, give him little less than divine honours, even though
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: they know him to be so covetous and base-minded that, notwithstanding all
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: his wealth, he will not part with one farthing of it to them as long as
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: he lives!
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "These and such like notions have that people imbibed, partly from their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: education, being bred in a country whose customs and laws are opposite to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: all such foolish maxims, and partly from their learning and studies--for
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: though there are but few in any town that are so wholly excused from
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: labour as to give themselves entirely up to their studies (these being
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: only such persons as discover from their childhood an extraordinary
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: capacity and disposition for letters), yet their children and a great
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: part of the nation, both men and women, are taught to spend those hours
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: in which they are not obliged to work in reading; and this they do
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: through the whole progress of life.  They have all their learning in
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: their own tongue, which is both a copious and pleasant language, and in
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: which a man can fully express his mind; it runs over a great tract of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: many countries, but it is not equally pure in all places.  They had never
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: so much as heard of the names of any of those philosophers that are so
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: famous in these parts of the world, before we went among them; and yet
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: they had made the same discoveries as the Greeks, both in music, logic,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: arithmetic, and geometry.  But as they are almost in everything equal to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the ancient philosophers, so they far exceed our modern logicians for
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: they have never yet fallen upon the barbarous niceties that our youth are
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: forced to learn in those trifling logical schools that are among us.  They
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: are so far from minding chimeras and fantastical images made in the mind
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: that none of them could comprehend what we meant when we talked to them
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of a man in the abstract as common to all men in particular (so that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: though we spoke of him as a thing that we could point at with our
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: fingers, yet none of them could perceive him) and yet distinct from every
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: one, as if he were some monstrous Colossus or giant; yet, for all this
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: ignorance of these empty notions, they knew astronomy, and were perfectly
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: acquainted with the motions of the heavenly bodies; and have many
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: instruments, well contrived and divided, by which they very accurately
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: compute the course and positions of the sun, moon, and stars.  But for
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the cheat of divining by the stars, by their oppositions or conjunctions,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: it has not so much as entered into their thoughts.  They have a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: particular sagacity, founded upon much observation, in judging of the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: weather, by which they know when they may look for rain, wind, or other
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: alterations in the air; but as to the philosophy of these things, the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: cause of the saltness of the sea, of its ebbing and flowing, and of the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: original and nature both of the heavens and the earth, they dispute of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: them partly as our ancient philosophers have done, and partly upon some
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: new hypothesis, in which, as they differ from them, so they do not in all
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: things agree among themselves.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "As to moral philosophy, they have the same disputes among them as we
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: have here.  They examine what are properly good, both for the body and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the mind; and whether any outward thing can be called truly _good_, or if
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: that term belong only to the endowments of the soul.  They inquire,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: likewise, into the nature of virtue and pleasure.  But their chief
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: dispute is concerning the happiness of a man, and wherein it
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: consists--whether in some one thing or in a great many.  They seem,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: indeed, more inclinable to that opinion that places, if not the whole,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: yet the chief part, of a man's happiness in pleasure; and, what may seem
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: more strange, they make use of arguments even from religion,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: notwithstanding its severity and roughness, for the support of that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: opinion so indulgent to pleasure; for they never dispute concerning
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: happiness without fetching some arguments from the principles of religion
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: as well as from natural reason, since without the former they reckon that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: all our inquiries after happiness must be but conjectural and defective.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "These are their religious principles:--That the soul of man is immortal,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and that God of His goodness has designed that it should be happy; and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: that He has, therefore, appointed rewards for good and virtuous actions,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and punishments for vice, to be distributed after this life.  Though
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: these principles of religion are conveyed down among them by tradition,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: they think that even reason itself determines a man to believe and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: acknowledge them; and freely confess that if these were taken away, no
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: man would be so insensible as not to seek after pleasure by all possible
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: means, lawful or unlawful, using only this caution--that a lesser
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: pleasure might not stand in the way of a greater, and that no pleasure
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: ought to be pursued that should draw a great deal of pain after it; for
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: they think it the maddest thing in the world to pursue virtue, that is a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: sour and difficult thing, and not only to renounce the pleasures of life,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: but willingly to undergo much pain and trouble, if a man has no prospect
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of a reward.  And what reward can there be for one that has passed his
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: whole life, not only without pleasure, but in pain, if there is nothing
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: to be expected after death?  Yet they do not place happiness in all sorts
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of pleasures, but only in those that in themselves are good and honest.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: There is a party among them who place happiness in bare virtue; others
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: think that our natures are conducted by virtue to happiness, as that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: which is the chief good of man.  They define virtue thus--that it is a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: living according to Nature, and think that we are made by God for that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: end; they believe that a man then follows the dictates of Nature when he
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: pursues or avoids things according to the direction of reason.  They say
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: that the first dictate of reason is the kindling in us a love and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: reverence for the Divine Majesty, to whom we owe both all that we have
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and, all that we can ever hope for.  In the next place, reason directs us
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: to keep our minds as free from passion and as cheerful as we can, and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: that we should consider ourselves as bound by the ties of good-nature and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: humanity to use our utmost endeavours to help forward the happiness of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: all other persons; for there never was any man such a morose and severe
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: pursuer of virtue, such an enemy to pleasure, that though he set hard
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: rules for men to undergo, much pain, many watchings, and other rigors,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: yet did not at the same time advise them to do all they could in order to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: relieve and ease the miserable, and who did not represent gentleness and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: good-nature as amiable dispositions.  And from thence they infer that if
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: a man ought to advance the welfare and comfort of the rest of mankind
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: (there being no virtue more proper and peculiar to our nature than to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: ease the miseries of others, to free from trouble and anxiety, in
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: furnishing them with the comforts of life, in which pleasure consists)
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Nature much more vigorously leads them to do all this for himself.  A
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: life of pleasure is either a real evil, and in that case we ought not to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: assist others in their pursuit of it, but, on the contrary, to keep them
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: from it all we can, as from that which is most hurtful and deadly; or if
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: it is a good thing, so that we not only may but ought to help others to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: it, why, then, ought not a man to begin with himself? since no man can be
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: more bound to look after the good of another than after his own; for
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Nature cannot direct us to be good and kind to others, and yet at the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: same time to be unmerciful and cruel to ourselves.  Thus as they define
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: virtue to be living according to Nature, so they imagine that Nature
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: prompts all people on to seek after pleasure as the end of all they do.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: They also observe that in order to our supporting the pleasures of life,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Nature inclines us to enter into society; for there is no man so much
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: raised above the rest of mankind as to be the only favourite of Nature,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: who, on the contrary, seems to have placed on a level all those that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: belong to the same species.  Upon this they infer that no man ought to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: seek his own conveniences so eagerly as to prejudice others; and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: therefore they think that not only all agreements between private persons
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: ought to be observed, but likewise that all those laws ought to be kept
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: which either a good prince has published in due form, or to which a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: people that is neither oppressed with tyranny nor circumvented by fraud
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: has consented, for distributing those conveniences of life which afford
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: us all our pleasures.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "They think it is an evidence of true wisdom for a man to pursue his own
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: advantage as far as the laws allow it, they account it piety to prefer
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the public good to one's private concerns, but they think it unjust for a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: man to seek for pleasure by snatching another man's pleasures from him;
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and, on the contrary, they think it a sign of a gentle and good soul for
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: a man to dispense with his own advantage for the good of others, and that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: by this means a good man finds as much pleasure one way as he parts with
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: another; for as he may expect the like from others when he may come to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: need it, so, if that should fail him, yet the sense of a good action, and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the reflections that he makes on the love and gratitude of those whom he
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: has so obliged, gives the mind more pleasure than the body could have
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: found in that from which it had restrained itself.  They are also
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: persuaded that God will make up the loss of those small pleasures with a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: vast and endless joy, of which religion easily convinces a good soul.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "Thus, upon an inquiry into the whole matter, they reckon that all our
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: actions, and even all our virtues, terminate in pleasure, as in our chief
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: end and greatest happiness; and they call every motion or state, either
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of body or mind, in which Nature teaches us to delight, a pleasure.  Thus
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: they cautiously limit pleasure only to those appetites to which Nature
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: leads us; for they say that Nature leads us only to those delights to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: which reason, as well as sense, carries us, and by which we neither
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: injure any other person nor lose the possession of greater pleasures, and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of such as draw no troubles after them.  But they look upon those
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: delights which men by a foolish, though common, mistake call pleasure, as
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: if they could change as easily the nature of things as the use of words,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: as things that greatly obstruct their real happiness, instead of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: advancing it, because they so entirely possess the minds of those that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: are once captivated by them with a false notion of pleasure that there is
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: no room left for pleasures of a truer or purer kind.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "There are many things that in themselves have nothing that is truly
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: delightful; on the contrary, they have a good deal of bitterness in them;
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and yet, from our perverse appetites after forbidden objects, are not
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: only ranked among the pleasures, but are made even the greatest designs,
