title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of life.  Among those who pursue these sophisticated pleasures they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: reckon such as I mentioned before, who think themselves really the better
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: for having fine clothes; in which they think they are doubly mistaken,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: both in the opinion they have of their clothes, and in that they have of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: themselves.  For if you consider the use of clothes, why should a fine
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: thread be thought better than a coarse one?  And yet these men, as if
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: they had some real advantages beyond others, and did not owe them wholly
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: to their mistakes, look big, seem to fancy themselves to be more
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: valuable, and imagine that a respect is due to them for the sake of a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: rich garment, to which they would not have pretended if they had been
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: more meanly clothed, and even resent it as an affront if that respect is
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: not paid them.  It is also a great folly to be taken with outward marks
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of respect, which signify nothing; for what true or real pleasure can one
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: man find in another's standing bare or making legs to him?  Will the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: bending another man's knees give ease to yours? and will the head's being
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: bare cure the madness of yours?  And yet it is wonderful to see how this
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: false notion of pleasure bewitches many who delight themselves with the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: fancy of their nobility, and are pleased with this conceit--that they are
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: descended from ancestors who have been held for some successions rich,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and who have had great possessions; for this is all that makes nobility
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: at present.  Yet they do not think themselves a whit the less noble,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: though their immediate parents have left none of this wealth to them, or
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: though they themselves have squandered it away.  The Utopians have no
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: better opinion of those who are much taken with gems and precious stones,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and who account it a degree of happiness next to a divine one if they can
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: purchase one that is very extraordinary, especially if it be of that sort
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of stones that is then in greatest request, for the same sort is not at
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: all times universally of the same value, nor will men buy it unless it be
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: dismounted and taken out of the gold.  The jeweller is then made to give
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: good security, and required solemnly to swear that the stone is true,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: that, by such an exact caution, a false one might not be bought instead
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of a true; though, if you were to examine it, your eye could find no
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: difference between the counterfeit and that which is true; so that they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: are all one to you, as much as if you were blind.  Or can it be thought
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: that they who heap up a useless mass of wealth, not for any use that it
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: is to bring them, but merely to please themselves with the contemplation
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of it, enjoy any true pleasure in it?  The delight they find is only a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: false shadow of joy.  Those are no better whose error is somewhat
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: different from the former, and who hide it out of their fear of losing
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: it; for what other name can fit the hiding it in the earth, or, rather,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the restoring it to it again, it being thus cut off from being useful
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: either to its owner or to the rest of mankind?  And yet the owner, having
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: hid it carefully, is glad, because he thinks he is now sure of it.  If it
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: should be stole, the owner, though he might live perhaps ten years after
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the theft, of which he knew nothing, would find no difference between his
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: having or losing it, for both ways it was equally useless to him.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "Among those foolish pursuers of pleasure they reckon all that delight in
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: hunting, in fowling, or gaming, of whose madness they have only heard,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: for they have no such things among them.  But they have asked us, 'What
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: sort of pleasure is it that men can find in throwing the dice?' (for if
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: there were any pleasure in it, they think the doing it so often should
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: give one a surfeit of it); 'and what pleasure can one find in hearing the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: barking and howling of dogs, which seem rather odious than pleasant
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: sounds?'  Nor can they comprehend the pleasure of seeing dogs run after a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: hare, more than of seeing one dog run after another; for if the seeing
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: them run is that which gives the pleasure, you have the same
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: entertainment to the eye on both these occasions, since that is the same
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: in both cases.  But if the pleasure lies in seeing the hare killed and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: torn by the dogs, this ought rather to stir pity, that a weak, harmless,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and fearful hare should be devoured by strong, fierce, and cruel dogs.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Therefore all this business of hunting is, among the Utopians, turned
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: over to their butchers, and those, as has been already said, are all
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: slaves, and they look on hunting as one of the basest parts of a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: butcher's work, for they account it both more profitable and more decent
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: to kill those beasts that are more necessary and useful to mankind,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: whereas the killing and tearing of so small and miserable an animal can
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: only attract the huntsman with a false show of pleasure, from which he
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: can reap but small advantage.  They look on the desire of the bloodshed,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: even of beasts, as a mark of a mind that is already corrupted with
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: cruelty, or that at least, by too frequent returns of so brutal a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: pleasure, must degenerate into it.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "Thus though the rabble of mankind look upon these, and on innumerable
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: other things of the same nature, as pleasures, the Utopians, on the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: contrary, observing that there is nothing in them truly pleasant,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: conclude that they are not to be reckoned among pleasures; for though
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: these things may create some tickling in the senses (which seems to be a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: true notion of pleasure), yet they imagine that this does not arise from
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the thing itself, but from a depraved custom, which may so vitiate a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: man's taste that bitter things may pass for sweet, as women with child
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: think pitch or tallow taste sweeter than honey; but as a man's sense,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: when corrupted either by a disease or some ill habit, does not change the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: nature of other things, so neither can it change the nature of pleasure.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "They reckon up several sorts of pleasures, which they call true ones;
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: some belong to the body, and others to the mind.  The pleasures of the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: mind lie in knowledge, and in that delight which the contemplation of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: truth carries with it; to which they add the joyful reflections on a well-
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: spent life, and the assured hopes of a future happiness.  They divide the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: pleasures of the body into two sorts--the one is that which gives our
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: senses some real delight, and is performed either by recruiting Nature
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and supplying those parts which feed the internal heat of life by eating
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and drinking, or when Nature is eased of any surcharge that oppresses it,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: when we are relieved from sudden pain, or that which arises from
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: satisfying the appetite which Nature has wisely given to lead us to the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: propagation of the species.  There is another kind of pleasure that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: arises neither from our receiving what the body requires, nor its being
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: relieved when overcharged, and yet, by a secret unseen virtue, affects
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the senses, raises the passions, and strikes the mind with generous
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: impressions--this is, the pleasure that arises from music.  Another kind
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of bodily pleasure is that which results from an undisturbed and vigorous

title: Utopia

author: More, Thomas, Saint

title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

author: More, Thomas, Saint

author: More, Thomas, Saint

author: More, Thomas, Saint

author: More, Thomas, Saint

author: More, Thomas, Saint

author: More, Thomas, Saint

title: Utopia

title: Utopia

author: More, Thomas, Saint

title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

title: Utopia

author: More, Thomas, Saint

title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

author: More, Thomas, Saint

author: More, Thomas, Saint

author: More, Thomas, Saint

author: More, Thomas, Saint

title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

author: More, Thomas, Saint

author: More, Thomas, Saint

author: More, Thomas, Saint

author: More, Thomas, Saint

author: More, Thomas, Saint

author: More, Thomas, Saint

author: More, Thomas, Saint

author: More, Thomas, Saint

author: More, Thomas, Saint

title: Utopia

text: human nature, is more practised by men than by any sort of beasts.  They,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: in opposition to the sentiments of almost all other nations, think that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: there is nothing more inglorious than that glory that is gained by war;
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and therefore, though they accustom themselves daily to military
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: exercises and the discipline of war, in which not only their men, but
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: their women likewise, are trained up, that, in cases of necessity, they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: may not be quite useless, yet they do not rashly engage in war, unless it
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: be either to defend themselves or their friends from any unjust
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: aggressors, or, out of good nature or in compassion, assist an oppressed
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: nation in shaking off the yoke of tyranny.  They, indeed, help their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: friends not only in defensive but also in offensive wars; but they never
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: do that unless they had been consulted before the breach was made, and,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: being satisfied with the grounds on which they went, they had found that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: all demands of reparation were rejected, so that a war was unavoidable.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: This they think to be not only just when one neighbour makes an inroad on
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: another by public order, and carries away the spoils, but when the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: merchants of one country are oppressed in another, either under pretence
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of some unjust laws, or by the perverse wresting of good ones.  This they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: count a juster cause of war than the other, because those injuries are
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: done under some colour of laws.  This was the only ground of that war in
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: which they engaged with the Nephelogetes against the Aleopolitanes, a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: little before our time; for the merchants of the former having, as they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: thought, met with great injustice among the latter, which (whether it was
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: in itself right or wrong) drew on a terrible war, in which many of their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: neighbours were engaged; and their keenness in carrying it on being
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: supported by their strength in maintaining it, it not only shook some
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: very flourishing states and very much afflicted others, but, after a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: series of much mischief ended in the entire conquest and slavery of the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Aleopolitanes, who, though before the war they were in all respects much
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: superior to the Nephelogetes, were yet subdued; but, though the Utopians
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: had assisted them in the war, yet they pretended to no share of the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: spoil.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "But, though they so vigorously assist their friends in obtaining
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: reparation for the injuries they have received in affairs of this nature,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: yet, if any such frauds were committed against themselves, provided no
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: violence was done to their persons, they would only, on their being
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: refused satisfaction, forbear trading with such a people.  This is not
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: because they consider their neighbours more than their own citizens; but,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: since their neighbours trade every one upon his own stock, fraud is a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: more sensible injury to them than it is to the Utopians, among whom the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: public, in such a case, only suffers, as they expect no thing in return
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: for the merchandise they export but that in which they so much abound,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and is of little use to them, the loss does not much affect them.  They
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: think, therefore, it would be too severe to revenge a loss attended with
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: so little inconvenience, either to their lives or their subsistence, with
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the death of many persons; but if any of their people are either killed
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: or wounded wrongfully, whether it be done by public authority, or only by
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: private men, as soon as they hear of it they send ambassadors, and demand
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: that the guilty persons may be delivered up to them, and if that is
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: denied, they declare war; but if it be complied with, the offenders are
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: condemned either to death or slavery.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "They would be both troubled and ashamed of a bloody victory over their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: enemies; and think it would be as foolish a purchase as to buy the most
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: valuable goods at too high a rate.  And in no victory do they glory so
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: much as in that which is gained by dexterity and good conduct without
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: bloodshed.  In such cases they appoint public triumphs, and erect
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: trophies to the honour of those who have succeeded; for then do they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: reckon that a man acts suitably to his nature, when he conquers his enemy
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: in such a way as that no other creature but a man could be capable of,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and that is by the strength of his understanding.  Bears, lions, boars,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: wolves, and dogs, and all other animals, employ their bodily force one
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: against another, in which, as many of them are superior to men, both in
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: strength and fierceness, so they are all subdued by his reason and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: understanding.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "The only design of the Utopians in war is to obtain that by force which,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: if it had been granted them in time, would have prevented the war; or, if
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: that cannot be done, to take so severe a revenge on those that have
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: injured them that they may be terrified from doing the like for the time
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: to come.  By these ends they measure all their designs, and manage them
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: so, that it is visible that the appetite of fame or vainglory does not
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: work so much on there as a just care of their own security.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "As soon as they declare war, they take care to have a great many
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: schedules, that are sealed with their common seal, affixed in the most
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: conspicuous places of their enemies' country.  This is carried secretly,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and done in many places all at once.  In these they promise great rewards
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: to such as shall kill the prince, and lesser in proportion to such as
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: shall kill any other persons who are those on whom, next to the prince
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: himself, they cast the chief balance of the war.  And they double the sum
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: to him that, instead of killing the person so marked out, shall take him
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: alive, and put him in their hands.  They offer not only indemnity, but
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: rewards, to such of the persons themselves that are so marked, if they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: will act against their countrymen.  By this means those that are named in
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: their schedules become not only distrustful of their fellow-citizens, but
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: are jealous of one another, and are much distracted by fear and danger;
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: for it has often fallen out that many of them, and even the prince
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: himself, have been betrayed, by those in whom they have trusted most; for
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the rewards that the Utopians offer are so immeasurably great, that there
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: is no sort of crime to which men cannot be drawn by them.  They consider
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the risk that those run who undertake such services, and offer a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: recompense proportioned to the danger--not only a vast deal of gold, but
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: great revenues in lands, that lie among other nations that are their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: friends, where they may go and enjoy them very securely; and they observe
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the promises they make of their kind most religiously.  They very much
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: approve of this way of corrupting their enemies, though it appears to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: others to be base and cruel; but they look on it as a wise course, to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: make an end of what would be otherwise a long war, without so much as
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: hazarding one battle to decide it.  They think it likewise an act of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: mercy and love to mankind to prevent the great slaughter of those that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: must otherwise be killed in the progress of the war, both on their own
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: side and on that of their enemies, by the death of a few that are most
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: guilty; and that in so doing they are kind even to their enemies, and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: pity them no less than their own people, as knowing that the greater part
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of them do not engage in the war of their own accord, but are driven into
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: it by the passions of their prince.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "If this method does not succeed with them, then they sow seeds of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: contention among their enemies, and animate the prince's brother, or some
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of the nobility, to aspire to the crown.  If they cannot disunite them by
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: domestic broils, then they engage their neighbours against them, and make
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: them set on foot some old pretensions, which are never wanting to princes
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: when they have occasion for them.  These they plentifully supply with
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: money, though but very sparingly with any auxiliary troops; for they are
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: so tender of their own people that they would not willingly exchange one
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of them, even with the prince of their enemies' country.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "But as they keep their gold and silver only for such an occasion, so,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: when that offers itself, they easily part with it; since it would be no
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: convenience to them, though they should reserve nothing of it to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: themselves.  For besides the wealth that they have among them at home,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: they have a vast treasure abroad; many nations round about them being
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: deep in their debt: so that they hire soldiers from all places for
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: carrying on their wars; but chiefly from the Zapolets, who live five
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: hundred miles east of Utopia.  They are a rude, wild, and fierce nation,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: who delight in the woods and rocks, among which they were born and bred
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: up.  They are hardened both against heat, cold, and labour, and know
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: nothing of the delicacies of life.  They do not apply themselves to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: agriculture, nor do they care either for their houses or their clothes:
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: cattle is all that they look after; and for the greatest part they live
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: either by hunting or upon rapine; and are made, as it were, only for war.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: They watch all opportunities of engaging in it, and very readily embrace
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: such as are offered them.  Great numbers of them will frequently go out,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and offer themselves for a very low pay, to serve any that will employ
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: them: they know none of the arts of life, but those that lead to the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: taking it away; they serve those that hire them, both with much courage
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and great fidelity; but will not engage to serve for any determined time,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and agree upon such terms, that the next day they may go over to the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: enemies of those whom they serve if they offer them a greater
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: encouragement; and will, perhaps, return to them the day after that upon
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: a higher advance of their pay.  There are few wars in which they make not
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: a considerable part of the armies of both sides: so it often falls out
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: that they who are related, and were hired in the same country, and so
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: have lived long and familiarly together, forgetting both their relations
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and former friendship, kill one another upon no other consideration than
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: that of being hired to it for a little money by princes of different
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: interests; and such a regard have they for money that they are easily
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: wrought on by the difference of one penny a day to change sides.  So
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: entirely does their avarice influence them; and yet this money, which
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: they value so highly, is of little use to them; for what they purchase
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: thus with their blood they quickly waste on luxury, which among them is
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: but of a poor and miserable form.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "This nation serves the Utopians against all people whatsoever, for they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: pay higher than any other.  The Utopians hold this for a maxim, that as
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: they seek out the best sort of men for their own use at home, so they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: make use of this worst sort of men for the consumption of war; and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: therefore they hire them with the offers of vast rewards to expose
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: themselves to all sorts of hazards, out of which the greater part never
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: returns to claim their promises; yet they make them good most religiously
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: to such as escape.  This animates them to adventure again, whenever there
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: is occasion for it; for the Utopians are not at all troubled how many of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: these happen to be killed, and reckon it a service done to mankind if
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: they could be a means to deliver the world from such a lewd and vicious
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: sort of people, that seem to have run together, as to the drain of human
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: nature.  Next to these, they are served in their wars with those upon
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: whose account they undertake them, and with the auxiliary troops of their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: other friends, to whom they join a few of their own people, and send some
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: man of eminent and approved virtue to command in chief.  There are two
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: sent with him, who, during his command, are but private men, but the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: first is to succeed him if he should happen to be either killed or taken;
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and, in case of the like misfortune to him, the third comes in his place;
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and thus they provide against all events, that such accidents as may
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: befall their generals may not endanger their armies.  When they draw out
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: troops of their own people, they take such out of every city as freely
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: offer themselves, for none are forced to go against their wills, since
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: they think that if any man is pressed that wants courage, he will not
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: only act faintly, but by his cowardice dishearten others.  But if an
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: invasion is made on their country, they make use of such men, if they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: have good bodies, though they are not brave; and either put them aboard
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: their ships, or place them on the walls of their towns, that being so
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: posted, they may find no opportunity of flying away; and thus either
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: shame, the heat of action, or the impossibility of flying, bears down
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: their cowardice; they often make a virtue of necessity, and behave
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: themselves well, because nothing else is left them.  But as they force no
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: man to go into any foreign war against his will, so they do not hinder
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: those women who are willing to go along with their husbands; on the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: contrary, they encourage and praise them, and they stand often next their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: husbands in the front of the army.  They also place together those who
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: are related, parents, and children, kindred, and those that are mutually
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: allied, near one another; that those whom nature has inspired with the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: greatest zeal for assisting one another may be the nearest and readiest
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: to do it; and it is matter of great reproach if husband or wife survive
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: one another, or if a child survives his parent, and therefore when they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: come to be engaged in action, they continue to fight to the last man, if
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: their enemies stand before them: and as they use all prudent methods to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: avoid the endangering their own men, and if it is possible let all the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: action and danger fall upon the troops that they hire, so if it becomes
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: necessary for themselves to engage, they then charge with as much courage
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: as they avoided it before with prudence: nor is it a fierce charge at
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: first, but it increases by degrees; and as they continue in action, they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: grow more obstinate, and press harder upon the enemy, insomuch that they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: will much sooner die than give ground; for the certainty that their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: children will be well looked after when they are dead frees them from all
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: that anxiety concerning them which often masters men of great courage;
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and thus they are animated by a noble and invincible resolution.  Their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: skill in military affairs increases their courage: and the wise
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: sentiments which, according to the laws of their country, are instilled
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: into them in their education, give additional vigour to their minds: for
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: as they do not undervalue life so as prodigally to throw it away, they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: are not so indecently fond of it as to preserve it by base and unbecoming
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: methods.  In the greatest heat of action the bravest of their youth, who
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: have devoted themselves to that service, single out the general of their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: enemies, set on him either openly or by ambuscade; pursue him everywhere,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and when spent and wearied out, are relieved by others, who never give
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: over the pursuit, either attacking him with close weapons when they can
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: get near him, or with those which wound at a distance, when others get in
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: between them.  So that, unless he secures himself by flight, they seldom
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: fail at last to kill or to take him prisoner.  When they have obtained a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: victory, they kill as few as possible, and are much more bent on taking
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: many prisoners than on killing those that fly before them.  Nor do they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: ever let their men so loose in the pursuit of their enemies as not to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: retain an entire body still in order; so that if they have been forced to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: engage the last of their battalions before they could gain the day, they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: will rather let their enemies all escape than pursue them when their own
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: army is in disorder; remembering well what has often fallen out to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: themselves, that when the main body of their army has been quite defeated
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and broken, when their enemies, imagining the victory obtained, have let
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: themselves loose into an irregular pursuit, a few of them that lay for a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: reserve, waiting a fit opportunity, have fallen on them in their chase,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and when straggling in disorder, and apprehensive of no danger, but
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: counting the day their own, have turned the whole action, and, wresting
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: out of their hands a victory that seemed certain and undoubted, while the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: vanquished have suddenly become victorious.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "It is hard to tell whether they are more dexterous in laying or avoiding
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: ambushes.  They sometimes seem to fly when it is far from their thoughts;
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and when they intend to give ground, they do it so that it is very hard
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: to find out their design.  If they see they are ill posted, or are like
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: to be overpowered by numbers, they then either march off in the night
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: with great silence, or by some stratagem delude their enemies.  If they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: retire in the day-time, they do it in such order that it is no less
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: dangerous to fall upon them in a retreat than in a march.  They fortify
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: their camps with a deep and large trench; and throw up the earth that is
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: dug out of it for a wall; nor do they employ only their slaves in this,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: but the whole army works at it, except those that are then upon the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: guard; so that when so many hands are at work, a great line and a strong
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: fortification is finished in so short a time that it is scarce credible.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Their armour is very strong for defence, and yet is not so heavy as to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: make them uneasy in their marches; they can even swim with it.  All that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: are trained up to war practise swimming.  Both horse and foot make great
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: use of arrows, and are very expert.  They have no swords, but fight with
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: a pole-axe that is both sharp and heavy, by which they thrust or strike
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: down an enemy.  They are very good at finding out warlike machines, and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: disguise them so well that the enemy does not perceive them till he feels
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the use of them; so that he cannot prepare such a defence as would render
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: them useless; the chief consideration had in the making them is that they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: may be easily carried and managed.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "If they agree to a truce, they observe it so religiously that no
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: provocations will make them break it.  They never lay their enemies'
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: country waste nor burn their corn, and even in their marches they take
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: all possible care that neither horse nor foot may tread it down, for they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: do not know but that they may have use for it themselves.  They hurt no
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: man whom they find disarmed, unless he is a spy.  When a town is
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: surrendered to them, they take it into their protection; and when they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: carry a place by storm they never plunder it, but put those only to the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: sword that oppose the rendering of it up, and make the rest of the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: garrison slaves, but for the other inhabitants, they do them no hurt; and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: if any of them had advised a surrender, they give them good rewards out
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of the estates of those that they condemn, and distribute the rest among
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: their auxiliary troops, but they themselves take no share of the spoil.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "When a war is ended, they do not oblige their friends to reimburse their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: expenses; but they obtain them of the conquered, either in money, which
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: they keep for the next occasion, or in lands, out of which a constant
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: revenue is to be paid them; by many increases the revenue which they draw
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: out from several countries on such occasions is now risen to above
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: 700,000 ducats a year.  They send some of their own people to receive
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: these revenues, who have orders to live magnificently and like princes,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: by which means they consume much of it upon the place; and either bring
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: over the rest to Utopia or lend it to that nation in which it lies.  This
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: they most commonly do, unless some great occasion, which falls out but
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: very seldom, should oblige them to call for it all.  It is out of these
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: lands that they assign rewards to such as they encourage to adventure on
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: desperate attempts.  If any prince that engages in war with them is
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: making preparations for invading their country, they prevent him, and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: make his country the seat of the war; for they do not willingly suffer
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: any war to break in upon their island; and if that should happen, they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: would only defend themselves by their own people; but would not call for
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: auxiliary troops to their assistance.
