text: OF THE RELIGIONS OF THE UTOPIANS
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "There are several sorts of religions, not only in different parts of the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: island, but even in every town; some worshipping the sun, others the moon
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: or one of the planets.  Some worship such men as have been eminent in
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: former times for virtue or glory, not only as ordinary deities, but as
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the supreme god.  Yet the greater and wiser sort of them worship none of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: these, but adore one eternal, invisible, infinite, and incomprehensible
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Deity; as a Being that is far above all our apprehensions, that is spread
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: over the whole universe, not by His bulk, but by His power and virtue;
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Him they call the Father of All, and acknowledge that the beginnings, the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: increase, the progress, the vicissitudes, and the end of all things come
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: only from Him; nor do they offer divine honours to any but to Him alone.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: And, indeed, though they differ concerning other things, yet all agree in
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: this: that they think there is one Supreme Being that made and governs
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the world, whom they call, in the language of their country, Mithras.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: They differ in this: that one thinks the god whom he worships is this
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Supreme Being, and another thinks that his idol is that god; but they all
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: agree in one principle, that whoever is this Supreme Being, He is also
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: that great essence to whose glory and majesty all honours are ascribed by
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the consent of all nations.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "By degrees they fall off from the various superstitions that are among
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: them, and grow up to that one religion that is the best and most in
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: request; and there is no doubt to be made, but that all the others had
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: vanished long ago, if some of those who advised them to lay aside their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: superstitions had not met with some unhappy accidents, which, being
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: considered as inflicted by heaven, made them afraid that the god whose
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: worship had like to have been abandoned had interposed and revenged
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: themselves on those who despised their authority.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "After they had heard from us an account of the doctrine, the course of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: life, and the miracles of Christ, and of the wonderful constancy of so
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: many martyrs, whose blood, so willingly offered up by them, was the chief
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: occasion of spreading their religion over a vast number of nations, it is
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: not to be imagined how inclined they were to receive it.  I shall not
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: determine whether this proceeded from any secret inspiration of God, or
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: whether it was because it seemed so favourable to that community of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: goods, which is an opinion so particular as well as so dear to them;
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: since they perceived that Christ and His followers lived by that rule,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and that it was still kept up in some communities among the sincerest
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: sort of Christians.  From whichsoever of these motives it might be, true
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: it is, that many of them came over to our religion, and were initiated
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: into it by baptism.  But as two of our number were dead, so none of the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: four that survived were in priests' orders, we, therefore, could only
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: baptise them, so that, to our great regret, they could not partake of the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: other sacraments, that can only be administered by priests, but they are
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: instructed concerning them and long most vehemently for them.  They have
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: had great disputes among themselves, whether one chosen by them to be a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: priest would not be thereby qualified to do all the things that belong to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: that character, even though he had no authority derived from the Pope,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and they seemed to be resolved to choose some for that employment, but
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: they had not done it when I left them.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "Those among them that have not received our religion do not fright any
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: from it, and use none ill that goes over to it, so that all the while I
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: was there one man was only punished on this occasion.  He being newly
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: baptised did, notwithstanding all that we could say to the contrary,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: dispute publicly concerning the Christian religion, with more zeal than
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: discretion, and with so much heat, that he not only preferred our worship
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: to theirs, but condemned all their rites as profane, and cried out
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: against all that adhered to them as impious and sacrilegious persons,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: that were to be damned to everlasting burnings.  Upon his having
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: frequently preached in this manner he was seized, and after trial he was
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: condemned to banishment, not for having disparaged their religion, but
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: for his inflaming the people to sedition; for this is one of their most
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: ancient laws, that no man ought to be punished for his religion.  At the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: first constitution of their government, Utopus having understood that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: before his coming among them the old inhabitants had been engaged in
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: great quarrels concerning religion, by which they were so divided among
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: themselves, that he found it an easy thing to conquer them, since,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: instead of uniting their forces against him, every different party in
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: religion fought by themselves.  After he had subdued them he made a law
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: that every man might be of what religion he pleased, and might endeavour
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: to draw others to it by the force of argument and by amicable and modest
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: ways, but without bitterness against those of other opinions; but that he
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: ought to use no other force but that of persuasion, and was neither to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: mix with it reproaches nor violence; and such as did otherwise were to be
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: condemned to banishment or slavery.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "This law was made by Utopus, not only for preserving the public peace,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: which he saw suffered much by daily contentions and irreconcilable heats,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: but because he thought the interest of religion itself required it.  He
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: judged it not fit to determine anything rashly; and seemed to doubt
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: whether those different forms of religion might not all come from God,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: who might inspire man in a different manner, and be pleased with this
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: variety; he therefore thought it indecent and foolish for any man to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: threaten and terrify another to make him believe what did not appear to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: him to be true.  And supposing that only one religion was really true,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and the rest false, he imagined that the native force of truth would at
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: last break forth and shine bright, if supported only by the strength of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: argument, and attended to with a gentle and unprejudiced mind; while, on
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the other hand, if such debates were carried on with violence and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: tumults, as the most wicked are always the most obstinate, so the best
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and most holy religion might be choked with superstition, as corn is with
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: briars and thorns; he therefore left men wholly to their liberty, that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: they might be free to believe as they should see cause; only he made a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: solemn and severe law against such as should so far degenerate from the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: dignity of human nature, as to think that our souls died with our bodies,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: or that the world was governed by chance, without a wise overruling
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Providence: for they all formerly believed that there was a state of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: rewards and punishments to the good and bad after this life; and they now
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: look on those that think otherwise as scarce fit to be counted men, since
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: they degrade so noble a being as the soul, and reckon it no better than a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: beast's: thus they are far from looking on such men as fit for human
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: society, or to be citizens of a well-ordered commonwealth; since a man of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: such principles must needs, as oft as he dares do it, despise all their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: laws and customs: for there is no doubt to be made, that a man who is
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: afraid of nothing but the law, and apprehends nothing after death, will
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: not scruple to break through all the laws of his country, either by fraud
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: or force, when by this means he may satisfy his appetites.  They never
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: raise any that hold these maxims, either to honours or offices, nor
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: employ them in any public trust, but despise them, as men of base and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: sordid minds.  Yet they do not punish them, because they lay this down as
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: a maxim, that a man cannot make himself believe anything he pleases; nor
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: do they drive any to dissemble their thoughts by threatenings, so that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: men are not tempted to lie or disguise their opinions; which being a sort
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of fraud, is abhorred by the Utopians: they take care indeed to prevent
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: their disputing in defence of these opinions, especially before the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: common people: but they suffer, and even encourage them to dispute
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: concerning them in private with their priest, and other grave men, being
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: confident that they will be cured of those mad opinions by having reason
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: laid before them.  There are many among them that run far to the other
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: extreme, though it is neither thought an ill nor unreasonable opinion,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and therefore is not at all discouraged.  They think that the souls of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: beasts are immortal, though far inferior to the dignity of the human
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: soul, and not capable of so great a happiness.  They are almost all of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: them very firmly persuaded that good men will be infinitely happy in
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: another state: so that though they are compassionate to all that are
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: sick, yet they lament no man's death, except they see him loath to part
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: with life; for they look on this as a very ill presage, as if the soul,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: conscious to itself of guilt, and quite hopeless, was afraid to leave the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: body, from some secret hints of approaching misery.  They think that such
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: a man's appearance before God cannot be acceptable to Him, who being
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: called on, does not go out cheerfully, but is backward and unwilling, and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: is as it were dragged to it.  They are struck with horror when they see
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: any die in this manner, and carry them out in silence and with sorrow,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and praying God that He would be merciful to the errors of the departed
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: soul, they lay the body in the ground: but when any die cheerfully, and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: full of hope, they do not mourn for them, but sing hymns when they carry
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: out their bodies, and commending their souls very earnestly to God: their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: whole behaviour is then rather grave than sad, they burn the body, and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: set up a pillar where the pile was made, with an inscription to the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: honour of the deceased.  When they come from the funeral, they discourse
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of his good life, and worthy actions, but speak of nothing oftener and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: with more pleasure than of his serenity at the hour of death.  They think
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: such respect paid to the memory of good men is both the greatest
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: incitement to engage others to follow their example, and the most
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: acceptable worship that can be offered them; for they believe that though
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: by the imperfection of human sight they are invisible to us, yet they are
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: present among us, and hear those discourses that pass concerning
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: themselves.  They believe it inconsistent with the happiness of departed
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: souls not to be at liberty to be where they will: and do not imagine them
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: capable of the ingratitude of not desiring to see those friends with whom
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: they lived on earth in the strictest bonds of love and kindness: besides,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: they are persuaded that good men, after death, have these affections; and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: all other good dispositions increased rather than diminished, and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: therefore conclude that they are still among the living, and observe all
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: they say or do.  From hence they engage in all their affairs with the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: greater confidence of success, as trusting to their protection; while
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: this opinion of the presence of their ancestors is a restraint that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: prevents their engaging in ill designs.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "They despise and laugh at auguries, and the other vain and superstitious
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: ways of divination, so much observed among other nations; but have great
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: reverence for such miracles as cannot flow from any of the powers of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: nature, and look on them as effects and indications of the presence of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the Supreme Being, of which they say many instances have occurred among
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: them; and that sometimes their public prayers, which upon great and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: dangerous occasions they have solemnly put up to God, with assured
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: confidence of being heard, have been answered in a miraculous manner.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "They think the contemplating God in His works, and the adoring Him for
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: them, is a very acceptable piece of worship to Him.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "There are many among them that upon a motive of religion neglect
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: learning, and apply themselves to no sort of study; nor do they allow
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: themselves any leisure time, but are perpetually employed, believing that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: by the good things that a man does he secures to himself that happiness
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: that comes after death.  Some of these visit the sick; others mend
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: highways, cleanse ditches, repair bridges, or dig turf, gravel, or stone.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Others fell and cleave timber, and bring wood, corn, and other
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: necessaries, on carts, into their towns; nor do these only serve the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: public, but they serve even private men, more than the slaves themselves
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: do: for if there is anywhere a rough, hard, and sordid piece of work to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: be done, from which many are frightened by the labour and loathsomeness
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of it, if not the despair of accomplishing it, they cheerfully, and of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: their own accord, take that to their share; and by that means, as they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: ease others very much, so they afflict themselves, and spend their whole
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: life in hard labour: and yet they do not value themselves upon this, nor
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: lessen other people's credit to raise their own; but by their stooping to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: such servile employments they are so far from being despised, that they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: are so much the more esteemed by the whole nation.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "Of these there are two sorts: some live unmarried and chaste, and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: abstain from eating any sort of flesh; and thus weaning themselves from
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: all the pleasures of the present life, which they account hurtful, they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: pursue, even by the hardest and painfullest methods possible, that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: blessedness which they hope for hereafter; and the nearer they approach
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: to it, they are the more cheerful and earnest in their endeavours after
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: it.  Another sort of them is less willing to put themselves to much toil,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and therefore prefer a married state to a single one; and as they do not
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: deny themselves the pleasure of it, so they think the begetting of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: children is a debt which they owe to human nature, and to their country;
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: nor do they avoid any pleasure that does not hinder labour; and therefore
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: eat flesh so much the more willingly, as they find that by this means
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: they are the more able to work: the Utopians look upon these as the wiser
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: sect, but they esteem the others as the most holy.  They would indeed
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: laugh at any man who, from the principles of reason, would prefer an
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: unmarried state to a married, or a life of labour to an easy life: but
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: they reverence and admire such as do it from the motives of religion.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: There is nothing in which they are more cautious than in giving their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: opinion positively concerning any sort of religion.  The men that lead
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: those severe lives are called in the language of their country
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Brutheskas, which answers to those we call Religious Orders.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "Their priests are men of eminent piety, and therefore they are but few,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: for there are only thirteen in every town, one for every temple; but when
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: they go to war, seven of these go out with their forces, and seven others
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: are chosen to supply their room in their absence; but these enter again
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: upon their employments when they return; and those who served in their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: absence, attend upon the high priest, till vacancies fall by death; for
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: there is one set over the rest.  They are chosen by the people as the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: other magistrates are, by suffrages given in secret, for preventing of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: factions: and when they are chosen, they are consecrated by the college
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of priests.  The care of all sacred things, the worship of God, and an
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: inspection into the manners of the people, are committed to them.  It is
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: a reproach to a man to be sent for by any of them, or for them to speak
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: to him in secret, for that always gives some suspicion: all that is
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: incumbent on them is only to exhort and admonish the people; for the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: power of correcting and punishing ill men belongs wholly to the Prince,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and to the other magistrates: the severest thing that the priest does is
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the excluding those that are desperately wicked from joining in their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: worship: there is not any sort of punishment more dreaded by them than
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: this, for as it loads them with infamy, so it fills them with secret
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: horrors, such is their reverence to their religion; nor will their bodies
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: be long exempted from their share of trouble; for if they do not very
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: quickly satisfy the priests of the truth of their repentance, they are
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: seized on by the Senate, and punished for their impiety.  The education
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of youth belongs to the priests, yet they do not take so much care of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: instructing them in letters, as in forming their minds and manners
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: aright; they use all possible methods to infuse, very early, into the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: tender and flexible minds of children, such opinions as are both good in
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: themselves and will be useful to their country, for when deep impressions
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of these things are made at that age, they follow men through the whole
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: course of their lives, and conduce much to preserve the peace of the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: government, which suffers by nothing more than by vices that rise out of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: ill opinions.  The wives of their priests are the most extraordinary
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: women of the whole country; sometimes the women themselves are made
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: priests, though that falls out but seldom, nor are any but ancient widows
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: chosen into that order.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "None of the magistrates have greater honour paid them than is paid the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: priests; and if they should happen to commit any crime, they would not be
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: questioned for it; their punishment is left to God, and to their own
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: consciences; for they do not think it lawful to lay hands on any man, how
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: wicked soever he is, that has been in a peculiar manner dedicated to God;
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: nor do they find any great inconvenience in this, both because they have
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: so few priests, and because these are chosen with much caution, so that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: it must be a very unusual thing to find one who, merely out of regard to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: his virtue, and for his being esteemed a singularly good man, was raised
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: up to so great a dignity, degenerate into corruption and vice; and if
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: such a thing should fall out, for man is a changeable creature, yet,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: there being few priests, and these having no authority but what rises out
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of the respect that is paid them, nothing of great consequence to the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: public can proceed from the indemnity that the priests enjoy.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "They have, indeed, very few of them, lest greater numbers sharing in the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: same honour might make the dignity of that order, which they esteem so
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: highly, to sink in its reputation; they also think it difficult to find
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: out many of such an exalted pitch of goodness as to be equal to that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: dignity, which demands the exercise of more than ordinary virtues.  Nor
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: are the priests in greater veneration among them than they are among
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: their neighbouring nations, as you may imagine by that which I think
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: gives occasion for it.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "When the Utopians engage in battle, the priests who accompany them to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the war, apparelled in their sacred vestments, kneel down during the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: action (in a place not far from the field), and, lifting up their hands
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: to heaven, pray, first for peace, and then for victory to their own side,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and particularly that it may be gained without the effusion of much blood
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: on either side; and when the victory turns to their side, they run in
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: among their own men to restrain their fury; and if any of their enemies
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: see them or call to them, they are preserved by that means; and such as
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: can come so near them as to touch their garments have not only their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: lives, but their fortunes secured to them; it is upon this account that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: all the nations round about consider them so much, and treat them with
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: such reverence, that they have been often no less able to preserve their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: own people from the fury of their enemies than to save their enemies from
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: their rage; for it has sometimes fallen out, that when their armies have
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: been in disorder and forced to fly, so that their enemies were running
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: upon the slaughter and spoil, the priests by interposing have separated
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: them from one another, and stopped the effusion of more blood; so that,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: by their mediation, a peace has been concluded on very reasonable terms;
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: nor is there any nation about them so fierce, cruel, or barbarous, as not
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: to look upon their persons as sacred and inviolable.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "The first and the last day of the month, and of the year, is a festival;
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: they measure their months by the course of the moon, and their years by
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the course of the sun: the first days are called in their language the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Cynemernes, and the last the Trapemernes, which answers in our language,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: to the festival that begins or ends the season.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "They have magnificent temples, that are not only nobly built, but
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: extremely spacious, which is the more necessary as they have so few of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: them; they are a little dark within, which proceeds not from any error in
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the architecture, but is done with design; for their priests think that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: too much light dissipates the thoughts, and that a more moderate degree
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of it both recollects the mind and raises devotion.  Though there are
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: many different forms of religion among them, yet all these, how various
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: soever, agree in the main point, which is the worshipping the Divine
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Essence; and, therefore, there is nothing to be seen or heard in their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: temples in which the several persuasions among them may not agree; for
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: every sect performs those rites that are peculiar to it in their private
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: houses, nor is there anything in the public worship that contradicts the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: particular ways of those different sects.  There are no images for God in
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: their temples, so that every one may represent Him to his thoughts
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: according to the way of his religion; nor do they call this one God by
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: any other name but that of Mithras, which is the common name by which
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: they all express the Divine Essence, whatsoever otherwise they think it
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: to be; nor are there any prayers among them but such as every one of them
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: may use without prejudice to his own opinion.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "They meet in their temples on the evening of the festival that concludes
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: a season, and not having yet broke their fast, they thank God for their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: good success during that year or month which is then at an end; and the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: next day, being that which begins the new season, they meet early in
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: their temples, to pray for the happy progress of all their affairs during
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: that period upon which they then enter.  In the festival which concludes
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the period, before they go to the temple, both wives and children fall on
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: their knees before their husbands or parents and confess everything in
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: which they have either erred or failed in their duty, and beg pardon for
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: it.  Thus all little discontents in families are removed, that they may
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: offer up their devotions with a pure and serene mind; for they hold it a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: great impiety to enter upon them with disturbed thoughts, or with a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: consciousness of their bearing hatred or anger in their hearts to any
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: person whatsoever; and think that they should become liable to severe
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: punishments if they presumed to offer sacrifices without cleansing their
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: hearts, and reconciling all their differences.  In the temples the two
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: sexes are separated, the men go to the right hand, and the women to the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: left; and the males and females all place themselves before the head and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: master or mistress of the family to which they belong, so that those who
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: have the government of them at home may see their deportment in public.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: And they intermingle them so, that the younger and the older may be set
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: by one another; for if the younger sort were all set together, they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: would, perhaps, trifle away that time too much in which they ought to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: beget in themselves that religious dread of the Supreme Being which is
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the greatest and almost the only incitement to virtue.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "They offer up no living creature in sacrifice, nor do they think it
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: suitable to the Divine Being, from whose bounty it is that these
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: creatures have derived their lives, to take pleasure in their deaths, or
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the offering up their blood.  They burn incense and other sweet odours,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and have a great number of wax lights during their worship, not out of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: any imagination that such oblations can add anything to the divine nature
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: (which even prayers cannot do), but as it is a harmless and pure way of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: worshipping God; so they think those sweet savours and lights, together
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: with some other ceremonies, by a secret and unaccountable virtue, elevate
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: men's souls, and inflame them with greater energy and cheerfulness during
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the divine worship.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "All the people appear in the temples in white garments; but the priest's
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: vestments are parti-coloured, and both the work and colours are
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: wonderful.  They are made of no rich materials, for they are neither
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: embroidered nor set with precious stones; but are composed of the plumes
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of several birds, laid together with so much art, and so neatly, that the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: true value of them is far beyond the costliest materials.  They say, that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: in the ordering and placing those plumes some dark mysteries are
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: represented, which pass down among their priests in a secret tradition
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: concerning them; and that they are as hieroglyphics, putting them in mind
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of the blessing that they have received from God, and of their duties,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: both to Him and to their neighbours.  As soon as the priest appears in
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: those ornaments, they all fall prostrate on the ground, with so much
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: reverence and so deep a silence, that such as look on cannot but be
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: struck with it, as if it were the effect of the appearance of a deity.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: After they have been for some time in this posture, they all stand up,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: upon a sign given by the priest, and sing hymns to the honour of God,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: some musical instruments playing all the while.  These are quite of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: another form than those used among us; but, as many of them are much
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: sweeter than ours, so others are made use of by us.  Yet in one thing
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: they very much exceed us: all their music, both vocal and instrumental,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: is adapted to imitate and express the passions, and is so happily suited
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: to every occasion, that, whether the subject of the hymn be cheerful, or
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: formed to soothe or trouble the mind, or to express grief or remorse, the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: music takes the impression of whatever is represented, affects and
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: kindles the passions, and works the sentiments deep into the hearts of
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the hearers.  When this is done, both priests and people offer up very
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: solemn prayers to God in a set form of words; and these are so composed,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: that whatsoever is pronounced by the whole assembly may be likewise
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: applied by every man in particular to his own condition.  In these they
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: acknowledge God to be the author and governor of the world, and the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: fountain of all the good they receive, and therefore offer up to him
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: their thanksgiving; and, in particular, bless him for His goodness in
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: ordering it so, that they are born under the happiest government in the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: world, and are of a religion which they hope is the truest of all others;
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: but, if they are mistaken, and if there is either a better government, or
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: a religion more acceptable to God, they implore His goodness to let them
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: know it, vowing that they resolve to follow him whithersoever he leads
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: them; but if their government is the best, and their religion the truest,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: then they pray that He may fortify them in it, and bring all the world
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: both to the same rules of life, and to the same opinions concerning
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Himself, unless, according to the unsearchableness of His mind, He is
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: pleased with a variety of religions.  Then they pray that God may give
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: them an easy passage at last to Himself, not presuming to set limits to
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Him, how early or late it should be; but, if it may be wished for without
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: derogating from His supreme authority, they desire to be quickly
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: delivered, and to be taken to Himself, though by the most terrible kind
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: of death, rather than to be detained long from seeing Him by the most
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: prosperous course of life.  When this prayer is ended, they all fall down
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: again upon the ground; and, after a little while, they rise up, go home
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: to dinner, and spend the rest of the day in diversion or military
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: exercises.
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: "Thus have I described to you, as particularly as I could, the
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: Constitution of that commonwealth, which I do not only think the best in
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: the world, but indeed the only commonwealth that truly deserves that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: name.  In all other places it is visible that, while people talk of a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: commonwealth, every man only seeks his own wealth; but there, where no
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: man has any property, all men zealously pursue the good of the public,
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and, indeed, it is no wonder to see men act so differently, for in other
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: commonwealths every man knows that, unless he provides for himself, how
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: flourishing soever the commonwealth may be, he must die of hunger, so
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: that he sees the necessity of preferring his own concerns to the public;
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: but in Utopia, where every man has a right to everything, they all know
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: that if care is taken to keep the public stores full no private man can
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: want anything; for among them there is no unequal distribution, so that
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: no man is poor, none in necessity, and though no man has anything, yet
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: they are all rich; for what can make a man so rich as to lead a serene
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: and cheerful life, free from anxieties; neither apprehending want
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: himself, nor vexed with the endless complaints of his wife?  He is not
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: afraid of the misery of his children, nor is he contriving how to raise a
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: portion for his daughters; but is secure in this, that both he and his
title: Utopia
author: More, Thomas, Saint

text: wife, his children and grand-children, to as many generations as he can

author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: give her an account of either. Of the States men she enquired, first,
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret

author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret

title: Cavendish, Margaret

title: Cavendish, Margaret

author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret

title: Cavendish, Margaret

title: Cavendish, Margaret

title: Cavendish, Margaret

title: Cavendish, Margaret

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: command you again to break them; for you may observe the progressive
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret

title: Cavendish, Margaret

author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: Natural? No, answered they: for there is but a Divine Faith, and as for
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: Reason it is onely Natural; but you Mortals are so puzled about this
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: Divine Faith, and Natural Reason, that you do not know well how to
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: distinguish them, but confound them both, which is the cause you have so
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: many divine Philosophers who make a Gallimafry both of Reason and Faith.
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: Then she asked, Whether pure Natural Philosophers were Cabbalists? They
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: answered, No; but onely your Mystical or Divine Philosophers, such as
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: study beyond Sense and Reason. she enquired further, Whether there was
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: any Cabbala in God, or whether God was full of Idea's? They answered,
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: There could be nothing in God, nor could God be full of any thing,
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: either forms or figures, but of himself; for God is the Perfection of
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: all things, and an Unexpressible Being, beyond the conception of any
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: Creature, either Natural or Supernatural. Then I pray inform me, said
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: the Empress, Whether the Jews Cabbala or any other, consist in Numbers?
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: The Spirits answered, No: for Numbers are odd, and different, and would
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: make a disagreement in the Cabbala. But, said she again, Is it a sin
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: then not to know or understand the Cabbala? God is so merciful, answered
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: they, and so just, that he will never damn the ignorant, and save onely
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: those that pretend to know him and his secret Counsels by their
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: Cabbala's; but he loves those that adore and worship him with fear and
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: reverence, and with a pure heart. she asked further, which of these two
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: Cabbala's was most approved, the Natural, or Theological? The
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: Theological, answered they, is mystical, and belongs onely to Faith; but
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: the Natural belongs to Reason. Then she asked them, Whether Divine Faith
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: was made out of Reason? No answered they, for Faith proceeds onely from
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: a Divine saving Grace, which is a peculiar Gift of God. How comes it
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: then, replied she, that Men, even those that are of several opinions,
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: have Faith more or less? A Natural Belief, answered they, is not a
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: Divine Faith. But, proceeded the Empress, How are you sure that God
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: cannot be known? The several Opinions you Mortals have of God, answered
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: they, are sufficient witnesses thereof. Well then, replied the Empress,
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: leaving this inquisitive knowledg of God, I pray inform me, whether you
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: Spirits give motion to Natural Bodies? No, answered they; but, on the
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: contrary, Natural material bodies give Spirits motion; for we Spirits,
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: being incorporeal, have no motion but from our Corporeal Vehicles, so
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: that we move by the help of our Bodies, and not the Bodies by our help;
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: for their quick and sudden motions. Then the Empress asked them, Whether
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: they could speak without a body, or bodily organs? No, said they; nor
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: could we have any bodily sense, but onely knowledg. she asked, Whether
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: they could have Knowledg without Body? Not a Natural, answered they, but
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: a Supernatural Knowledg, which is a far better Knowledg then a Natural.
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: They answered, Single or particular created Spirits, have not; for not
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: of all things. The Empress asked them further, Whether Spirits had
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: were living Bodies? They are Self-moving Bodies, answered they, and
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: therefore they must needs be living; for nothing can move it self,
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: without it hath life. Then, said she, it must necessarily follow, that
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: this living, Self-moving Body gives motion to the Spirit, and not the
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: Spirit motion to the Body, as its Vehicle. You say very true, answered
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: they, and we told you this before. Then the Empress asked them, Of what
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: forms of Matter those Vehicles were? They said they were of several
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: different forms; some gross and dense, and others more pure, rare, and
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: answered they; for we being incorporeal, cannot leave or quit them: but
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: a little World, then Man was so too. she asked again, Whether our
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

text: That in former Ages they had been as wise as they are in this present,
title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret
author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World

title: Cavendish, Margaret

title: Cavendish, Margaret

author: The Description of a New World, Called The Blazing-World
